member.name: T:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.AffineTransform2DInterpolationMode
member.summary:
The interpolation mode to be used with the AffineTransform2D effect to scale the image. There are 6 scale modes that range in quality and speed.
D2D1_2DAFFINETRANSFORM_INTERPOLATION_MODE

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.AffineTransform2DInterpolationMode.NearestNeighbor
member.summary: Samples the nearest single point and uses that. This mode uses less processing time, but outputs the lowest quality image.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.AffineTransform2DInterpolationMode.Linear
member.summary: Uses a four point sample and linear interpolation. This mode uses more processing time than the nearest neighbor mode, but outputs a higher quality image.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.AffineTransform2DInterpolationMode.Cubic
member.summary: Uses a 16 sample cubic kernel for interpolation. This mode uses the most processing time, but outputs a higher quality image.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.AffineTransform2DInterpolationMode.MultisampleLinear
member.summary: Uses 4 linear samples within a single pixel for good edge anti-aliasing. This mode is good for scaling down by small amounts on images with few pixels.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.AffineTransform2DInterpolationMode.Anisotropic
member.summary: Uses anisotropic filtering to sample a pattern according to the transformed shape of the bitmap.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.AffineTransform2DInterpolationMode.HighQualityCubic
member.summary: Uses a variable size high quality cubic kernel to perform a pre-downscale of the image if downscaling is involved in the transform matrix. Then uses the cubic interpolation mode for the final output.

member.name: T:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.AlphaMode
member.summary:
Specifies how the alpha value of a bitmap or render target should be treated.
D2D1_ALPHA_MODE

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.AlphaMode.Unknown
member.summary: The alpha value might not be meaningful.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.AlphaMode.Premultiplied
member.summary: The alpha value has been premultiplied. Each color is first scaled by the alpha value. The alpha value itself is the same in both straight and premultiplied alpha. Typically, no color channel value is greater than the alpha channel value. If a color channel value in a premultiplied format is greater than the alpha channel, the standard source-over blending math results in an additive blend.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.AlphaMode.Straight
member.summary: The alpha value has not been premultiplied. The alpha channel indicates the transparency of the color.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.AlphaMode.Ignore
member.summary: The alpha value is ignored.

D2D1_ANTIALIAS_MODE

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.AntialiasMode.PerPrimitive
member.summary: Edges are antialiased using the Direct2D per-primitive method of high-quality antialiasing.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.AntialiasMode.Aliased
member.summary: Objects are aliased in most cases.

member.name: T:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.BezierSegment
member.summary:
Represents a cubic bezier segment drawn between two points.
D2D1_BEZIER_SEGMENT
member.remarks:
A cubic Bezier curve is defined by four points: a start point, an end point (point3), and two control points (point1 and point2). A Bezier segment does not contain a property for the starting point of the curve; it defines only the end point. The beginning point of the curve is the current point of the path to which the Bezier curve is added.
The two control points of a cubic Bezier curve behave like magnets, attracting portions of what would otherwise be a straight line toward themselves and producing a curve. The first control point, point1, affects the beginning portion of the curve; the second control point, point2, affects the ending portion of the curve.
Note: The curve doesn't necessarily pass through either of the control points; each control point moves its portion of the line toward itself, but not through itself.

member.name: P:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.BezierSegment.Point1
member.summary: The first control point for the Bezier segment.

member.name: P:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.BezierSegment.Point2
member.summary: The second control point for the Bezier segment.

member.name: P:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.BezierSegment.Point3
member.summary: The end point for the Bezier segment.

member.name: T:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.BitmapOptions
member.summary:
Specifies how a bitmap can be used.
D2D1_BITMAP_OPTIONS
member.remarks:
BitmapOptions.None implies that none of the flags are set. This means that the bitmap can be used for drawing from, cannot be set as a target and cannot be read from by the CPU.
BitmapOptions.Target means that the bitmap can be specified as a target in . If you also specify the BitmapOptions.CannotDraw flag the bitmap can be used a target but, it cannot be drawn from. Attempting to draw with a bitmap that has both flags set will result in the device context being put into an error state with D2DERR_BITMAP_CANNOT_DRAW.
BitmapOptions.CpuRead means that the bitmap can be mapped by using . This flag requires BitmapOptions.CannotDraw and cannot be combined with any other flags. The bitmap must be updated with the CopyFromBitmap or CopyFromRenderTarget methods.
NOTE: You should only use BitmapOptions.CannotDraw when the purpose of the bitmap is to be a target only or when the bitmap will be mapped.
BitmapOptions.GdiCompatible means that it is possible to get a DC associated with this bitmap. This must be used in conjunction with BitmapOptions.Target. The DxgiFormat must be either or .

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.BitmapOptions.None
member.summary: The bitmap is created with default properties.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.BitmapOptions.Target
member.summary: The bitmap can be used as a device context target.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.BitmapOptions.CannotDraw
member.summary: The bitmap cannot be used as an input.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.BitmapOptions.CpuRead
member.summary: The bitmap can be read from the CPU by using . This flag requires and cannot be combined with any other flags.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.BitmapOptions.GdiCompatible
member.summary: The bitmap works with ID2D1GdiInteropRenderTarget::GetDC(). (unsupported)

member.name: T:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.BitmapSourceInterpolationMode
member.summary:
The interpolation mode used to scale the image in the Bitmap source effect. If the mode disables the mipmap, then BitmapSource will cache the image at the resolution determined by the Scale and EnableDpiCorrection properties.
D2D1_BITMAPSOURCE_INTERPOLATION_MODE

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.BitmapSourceInterpolationMode.NearestNeighbor
member.summary: Samples the nearest single point and uses that. This mode uses less processing time, but outputs the lowest quality image. Doesn't generate a mipmap.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.BitmapSourceInterpolationMode.Linear
member.summary: Uses a four point sample and linear interpolation. This mode uses more processing time than the nearest neighbor mode, but outputs a higher quality image. Doesn't generate a mipmap.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.BitmapSourceInterpolationMode.Cubic
member.summary: Uses a 16 sample cubic kernel for interpolation. This mode uses the most processing time, but outputs a higher quality image. Doesn't generate a mipmap.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.BitmapSourceInterpolationMode.Fant
member.summary: Uses the WIC Fant interpolation, the same as the IWICBitmapScaler interface. Doesn't generate a mipmap.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.BitmapSourceInterpolationMode.MipmapLinear
member.summary: Generates mipmap chain in system memory using bilinear interpolation. For each mipmap the effect scales to the nearest multiple of 0.5 using bilinear interpolation and then scales the remaining amount using linear interpolation.

member.summary: Repeats the pixels from the edges of the image.

member.summary: Uses pixels from the opposite end edge of the image.

member.name: T:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.BorderMode
member.summary:
Specifies how various effects handle the rectangle falling on fractional pixel coordinates.
D2D1_BORDER_MODE

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.BorderMode.Soft
member.summary:
For cropping, if the crop rectangle falls on fractional pixel coordinates, the effect applies antialiasing which results in a soft edge.
For sampling, the effect pads the image with transparent black pixels as it interpolates, resulting in a soft edge.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.BorderMode.Hard
member.summary:
If the crop rectangle falls on fractional pixel coordinates, the effect clamps which results in a hard edge.
For sampling, the effect clamps the output to the size of the input image.

member.summary:
Specifies which ICC rendering intent the Color management effect should use.
D2D1_COLORMANAGEMENT_RENDERING_INTENT

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.ColorManagementRenderingIntent.Perceptual
member.summary: The effect compresses or expands the full color gamut of the image to fill the color gamut of the device, so that gray balance is preserved but colorimetric accuracy may not be preserved.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.ColorManagementRenderingIntent.RelativeColorimetric
member.summary: The effect preserves the chroma of colors in the image at the possible expense of hue and lightness.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.ColorManagementRenderingIntent.Saturation
member.summary: The effect adjusts colors that fall outside the range of colors the output device renders to the closest color available. It does not preserve the white point.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.ColorManagementRenderingIntent.AbsoluteColorimetric
member.summary: The effect adjusts any colors that fall outside the range that the output device can render to the closest color that can be rendered. The effect does not change the other colors and preserves the white point.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.ColorMatrixAlphaMode.Straight

member.name: T:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.CompositeMode
member.summary: Specifies a compositing mode. See D2D1_COMPOSITE_MODE and Direct2D Composite effect for more info.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.CompositeMode.SourceOver
member.summary: The standard source-over-destination blend mode.
member.remarks: O = S + (1 - SA) * D

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.CompositeMode.DestinationOver
member.summary: The destination is rendered over the source.
member.remarks: O = (1 - DA) * S + D

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.CompositeMode.SourceIn
member.summary: Performs a logical clip of the source pixels against the destination pixels.
member.remarks: O = DA * S

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.CompositeMode.DestinationIn
member.summary: The inverse of the SourceIn operation.
member.remarks: O = SA * D

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.CompositeMode.SourceOut
member.summary: The logical inverse of the SourceIn operation.
member.remarks: O = (1 - DA) * S

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.CompositeMode.DestinationOut
member.summary: The logical inverse to the DestinationIn operation.
member.remarks: O = (1 - SA) * D

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.CompositeMode.SourceAtop
member.summary: Writes the source pixels over the destination where there are destination pixels.
member.remarks: O = DA * S + (1 - SA) * D

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.CompositeMode.DestinationAtop
member.summary: The logical inverse of the SourceAtop operation.
member.remarks: O = (1 - DA) * S + SA * D

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.CompositeMode.Xor
member.summary: The source is inverted with the destination.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.CompositeMode.Plus
member.summary: The channel components are summed.
member.remarks: O = S + D

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.CompositeMode.SourceCopy
member.summary: The source is copied to the destination; the destination pixels are ignored.
member.remarks: O = S

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.CompositeMode.BoundedSourceCopy
member.summary: Equivalent to SourceCopy, but pixels outside of the source bounds are unchanged.
member.remarks: O = S (only where source exists)

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.CompositeMode.MaskInvert
member.summary: Destination colors are inverted according to a source mask.

member.name: T:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.ConvolveMatrixScaleMode
member.summary:
The interpolation mode the Convolve matrix effect uses to scale the image to the corresponding kernel unit length. There are six scale modes that range in quality and speed.
D2D1_CONVOLVEMATRIX_SCALE_MODE

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.ConvolveMatrixScaleMode.NearestNeighbor
member.summary: Samples the nearest single point and uses that. This mode uses less processing time, but outputs the lowest quality image.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.ConvolveMatrixScaleMode.Linear
member.summary: Uses a four point sample and linear interpolation. This mode uses more processing time than the nearest neighbor mode, but outputs a higher quality image.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.ConvolveMatrixScaleMode.Cubic
member.summary: Uses a 16 sample cubic kernel for interpolation. This mode uses the most processing time, but outputs a higher quality image.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.ConvolveMatrixScaleMode.MultisampleLinear
member.summary: Uses 4 linear samples within a single pixel for good edge anti-aliasing. This mode is good for scaling down by small amounts on images with few pixels.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.ConvolveMatrixScaleMode.Anisotropic
member.summary: Uses anisotropic filtering to sample a pattern according to the transformed shape of the bitmap.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.ConvolveMatrixScaleMode.HighQualityCubic
member.summary: Uses a variable size high quality cubic kernel to perform a pre-downscale of the image if downscaling is involved in the transform matrix. Then uses the cubic interpolation mode for the final output.

member.name: T:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.DashStyle
member.summary:
Describes the sequence of dashes and gaps in a stroke.
D2D1_DASH_STYLE

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.DashStyle.Solid
member.summary: A solid line with no breaks.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.DashStyle.Dash
member.summary:
A dash followed by a gap of equal length. The dash and the gap are each twice as long as the stroke thickness.
The equivalent dash array is {2, 2}.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.DashStyle.Dot
member.summary:
A dot followed by a longer gap.
The equivalent dash array is {0, 2}.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.DashStyle.DashDot
member.summary:
A dash, followed by a gap, followed by a dot, followed by another gap.
The equivalent dash array is {2, 2, 0, 2}.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.DashStyle.DashDotDot
member.summary:
A dash, followed by a gap, followed by a dot, followed by another gap, followed by another dot, followed by another gap.
The equivalent dash array is {2, 2, 0, 2, 0, 2}.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.DashStyle.Custom
member.summary: The dash pattern is specified by an array of floating-point values.

member.name: M:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.DeviceContextExtensions.TryFlush(PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.IDeviceContext)
member.summary: Flushes the device context, if possible.
member.returns: The error code returned from ID2D1RenderTarget::Flush().
member.remarks: You can use this method to query the state of the device context. If Direct2D1Error.WrongState is returned, then the device context is not in the drawing state (BeginDraw() has not been called). This can be helpful when trying to build a command list.

This specifies options that apply to the device context for its lifetime.
D2D1_DEVICE_CONTEXT_OPTIONS

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.DeviceContextOptions.None
member.summary: The device context is created with default options.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.DeviceContextOptions.EnableMultithreadedOptimizations
member.summary: Distribute rendering work across multiple threads. Refer to Improving the performance of Direct2D apps for additional notes on the use of this flag.

member.name: T:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.DeviceContextProperties
member.summary:
Contains rendering options (hardware or software), pixel format, DPI information, remoting options, and Direct3D support requirements for a device context.
D2D1_RENDER_TARGET_PROPERTIES

member.name: P:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.DeviceContextProperties.Type
member.summary: A value that specifies whether the render target should force hardware or software rendering. A value of specifies that the render target should use hardware rendering if it is available; otherwise, it uses software rendering. Note that WIC bitmap render targets do not support hardware rendering.

member.name: P:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.DeviceContextProperties.PixelFormat
member.summary:
The pixel format and alpha mode of the render target. You can use to specify that Direct2D should select the pixel format and alpha mode for you.
For a list of pixel formats and alpha modes supported by each render target, see Supported Pixel Formats and Alpha Modes.

member.name: P:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.DeviceContextProperties.Dpi
member.summary: The DPI of the render target. To use the default DPI, set this to (0, 0).

member.name: P:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.DeviceContextProperties.Usage
member.summary: A value that specifies how the device context is remoted and whether it should be GDI-compatible. Set to to create a render target that is not compatible with GDI and uses Direct3D command-stream remoting if it is available.

member.name: P:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.DeviceContextProperties.MinLevel
member.summary: A value that specifies the minimum Direct3D feature level required for hardware rendering. If the specified minimum level is not available, the device context uses software rendering if the type member is set to ; if type is set to , device context creation fails. A value of indicates that Direct2D should determine whether the Direct3D feature level of the device is adequate. This field is used only when creating and objects.

member.name: T:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.DeviceContextType
member.summary:
Describes whether a device context uses hardware or software rendering, or if Direct2D should select the rendering mode.
D2D1_RENDER_TARGET_TYPE
member.remarks: Not every render target supports hardware rendering. For more information, see the Render Targets Overview.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.DeviceContextType.Default
member.summary: The device context uses hardware rendering, if available; otherwise, it uses software rendering.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.DeviceContextType.Software
member.summary: The device context uses software rendering only.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.DeviceContextType.Hardware
member.summary: The device context uses hardware rendering only.

member.name: T:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.DeviceContextUsage
member.summary:
Describes how a device context is remoted and whether it should be GDI-compatible. This enumeration allows a bitwise combination of its member values.
D2D1_RENDER_TARGET_USAGE

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.DeviceContextUsage.None
member.summary: The render target attempts to use Direct3D command-stream remoting and uses bitmap remoting if stream remoting fails. The render target is not GDI-compatible.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.DeviceContextUsage.ForceBitmapRemoting
member.summary: The render target renders content locally and sends it to the terminal services client as a bitmap.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.DeviceContextUsage.GdiCompatible
member.summary: The render target can be used efficiently with GDI.

member.summary:
Specifies the optimization mode for the Directional blur effect.
D2D1_DIRECTIONALBLUR_OPTIMIZATION

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.DirectionalBlurOptimization.Speed
member.summary: Applies internal optimizations such as pre-scaling at relatively small radii. Uses linear filtering.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.DirectionalBlurOptimization.Balanced
member.summary: Uses the same optimization thresholds as Speed mode, but uses trilinear filtering.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.DirectionalBlurOptimization.Quality
member.summary: Only uses internal optimizations with large blur radii, where approximations are less likely to be visible. Uses trilinear filtering.

member.name: T:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.DistantDiffuseScaleMode
member.summary:
The interpolation mode the Distant Diffuse effect uses to scale the image to the corresponding kernel unit length. There are six scale modes that range in quality and speed.
D2D1_DISTANTDIFFUSE_SCALE_MODE

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.DistantDiffuseScaleMode.NearestNeighbor
member.summary: Samples the nearest single point and uses that. This mode uses less processing time, but outputs the lowest quality image.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.DistantDiffuseScaleMode.Linear
member.summary: Uses a four point sample and linear interpolation. This mode uses more processing time than the nearest neighbor mode, but outputs a higher quality image.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.DistantDiffuseScaleMode.Cubic
member.summary: Uses a 16 sample cubic kernel for interpolation. This mode uses the most processing time, but outputs a higher quality image.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.DistantDiffuseScaleMode.MultisampleLinear
member.summary: Uses 4 linear samples within a single pixel for good edge anti-aliasing. This mode is good for scaling down by small amounts on images with few pixels.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.DistantDiffuseScaleMode.Anisotropic
member.summary: Uses anisotropic filtering to sample a pattern according to the transformed shape of the bitmap.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.DistantDiffuseScaleMode.HighQualityCubic
member.summary: Uses a variable size high quality cubic kernel to perform a pre-downscale of the image if downscaling is involved in the transform matrix. Then uses the cubic interpolation mode for the final output.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.FactoryType.Multithreaded

member.name: T:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.FillMode
member.summary:
Specifies how the intersecting areas of geometries or figures are combined to form the area of the composite geometry.
See D2D1_FILL_MODE for more information.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.FillMode.Alternate
member.summary: Determines whether a point is in the fill region by drawing a ray from that point to infinity in any direction, and then counting the number of path segments within the given shape that the ray crosses. If this number is odd, the point is in the fill region; if even, the point is outside the fill region.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.FillMode.Winding
member.summary: Determines whether a point is in the fill region of the path by drawing a ray from that point to infinity in any direction, and then examining the places where a segment of the shape crosses the ray. Starting with a count of zero, add one each time a segment crosses the ray from left to right and subtract one each time a path segment crosses the ray from right to left, as long as left and right are seen from the perspective of the ray. After counting the crossings, if the result is zero, then the point is outside the path. Otherwise, it is inside the path.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.FlatteningTolerance.Default

member.summary: Computes the appropriate flattening tolerance to pass to APIs that take a flattening tolerance (e.g., ).

The optimization mode for the Gaussian blur effect.
D2D1_GAUSSIANBLUR_OPTIMIZATION

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.GaussianBlurOptimization.Speed
member.summary: Applies internal optimizations such as pre-scaling at relatively small radii. Uses linear filtering.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.GaussianBlurOptimization.Balanced
member.summary: Uses the same optimization thresholds as Speed mode, but uses trilinear filtering.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.GaussianBlurOptimization.Quality
member.summary: Only uses internal optimizations with large blur radii, where approximations are less likely to be visible. Uses trilinear filtering.

member.name: T:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.ICommandSink
member.summary:
The command sink is implemented by you for an application when you want to receive a playback of the commands recorded in a command list. A typical usage will be for transforming the command list into another format such as XPS when some degree of conversion between the Direct2D primitives and the target format is required.
The command sink interface doesn't have any resource creation methods on it. The resources are still logically bound to the Direct2D device on which the command list was created and will be passed in to the command sink implementation.
This interface corresponds to the following Direct2D interfaces: ID2D1CommandSink ID2D1CommandSink1 ID2D1CommandSink2 ID2D1CommandSink3 ID2D1CommandSink4 ID2D1CommandSink5
member.remarks: To implement this yourself, such as to process the commands stored in an by calling , create a class that derives from and that also derives from this interface.

member.name: T:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.IDeviceContext
member.summary:
Represents a set of state and command buffers that are used to render to a target.
The device context can render to a target bitmap or a command list.
This interface corresponds to the follow Direct2D interfaces: ID2D1RenderTarget ID2D1DeviceContext ID2D1DeviceContext1 ID2D1DeviceContext2 ID2D1DeviceContext3 ID2D1DeviceContext4 ID2D1DeviceContext5 ID2D1DeviceContext6
member.remarks: Any resource created from a device context can be shared with any other resource created from a device context when both contexts are created on the same .

member.remarks: This indicates the mapping from pixel space to device-independent space for the device context.

member.summary: Gets the maximum pixel size of any one bitmap dimension supported by the render target.
member.remarks: This method returns the maximum texture size of the Direct3D device. Note: The software renderer and WARP devices return the value of 16 megapixels (16*1024*1024). You can create a Direct2D texture that is this size, but not a Direct3D texture that is this size.

member.summary: Returns the size of the current target in device pixels.

member.name: P:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.IDeviceContext.Size
member.summary: Returns the size of the current target in device-independent pixels.

member.param: The render target properties to test.
member.returns: true if the specified device context properties are supported by this device context.
member.remarks: This method does not evaluate the DPI settings specified by the deviceContextProperties parameter.

member.summary: Gets the device associated with a device context.
member.remarks: Some functionality for controlling all of the resources for a set of device contexts is maintained only on an object.

member.name: M:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.IDeviceContext.GetTarget
member.summary: Gets the target currently associated with the device context.
member.returns: The target currently associated with the device context.
member.remarks:
If a target is not associated with the device context, this method will return null.
If the currently selected target is a bitmap rather than a command list, the application can gain access to the initial bitmaps created by using one of the following methods: , , , .
It is not possible for an application to destroy these bitmaps. All of these bitmaps are bindable as bitmap targets. However not all of these bitmaps can be used as bitmap sources for methods.
will always create bitmaps that are usable as a bitmap source.
When using , will copy from the HDC to the original bitmap associated with it. will copy from the original bitmap to the HDC.
objects will be locked in the following circumstances:
BeginDraw has been called and the currently selected target bitmap is an .
An is set as the target of a device context after BeginDraw has been called and before EndDraw has been called.
Any of the .Copy* methods are called with an as either the source or detination.
objects will be unlocked in the following circumstances:
EndDraw is called and the currently selected target bitmap is an .
An is removed as the target of a device context between the calls to BeginDraw and EndDraw.
Any of the .Copy* methods are called with an as either the source or destination.
Direct2D will only lock bitmaps that are not currently locked.
will throw if there are any outstanding references to the original bitmap associated with the device context.
Although the target can be a command list, it cannot be any other type of image. It cannot be an effect.

member.name: M:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.IDeviceContext.SetTarget(PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.IDeviceImage)
member.summary: The bitmap or command list to which the Direct2D device context will now render.
member.param: The bitmap or command list to which the Direct2D device context will render.
member.remarks:
The target can be changed at any time, including while the context is drawing.
The target can be either a bitmap created with the D2D1_BITMAP_OPTIONS_TARGET flag, or it can be a command list. Other kinds of images cannot be set as a target. For example, you cannot set an effect as target. If the target is not valid the context will enter the error state.
You cannot use SetTarget to render to a bitmap/command list from multiple device contexts simultaneously. An image is considered â€œbeing rendered toâ€ if it has ever been set on a device context within a BeginDraw/EndDraw timespan. If an attempt is made to render to an image through multiple device contexts, all subsequent device contexts after the first will enter an error state.
Callers wishing to attach an image to a second device context should first call EndDraw on the first device context.
Note: Changing the target does not change the bitmap that an HWND device context presents from, nor does it change the bitmap that a DC device context blts to/from.
This API makes it easy for an application to use a bitmap as a source (like in DrawBitmap) and as a destination at the same time. Attempting to use a bitmap as a source on the same device context to which it is bound as a target will put the device context into the error state.
It is acceptable to have a bitmap bound as a target bitmap on multiple render targets at once. Applications that do this must properly synchronize rendering with or .
You can change the target at any time, including while the context is drawing.
You can set the target to null, in which case drawing calls will put the device context into an error state with . Calling SetTarget with a null target does not restore the original target bitmap to the device context.
If the device context has an outstanding HDC, the context will enter the error state. The target will not be changed.
If the bitmap and the device context are not in the same resource domain, the context will enter an error state. The target will not be changed.
returns the size of the current target bitmap (or 0, 0) if there is no bitmap bound). returns the pixel size of the current bitmap scaled by the DPI of the render target. SetTarget does not affect the DPI of the render target.
returns the pixel format of the current target bitmap, or if there is none.
copies from the currently bound target bitmap.

member.name: P:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.IDeviceContext.PrimitiveBlend
member.summary: Gets or sets the primitive blend used by the device context. The default is .
member.remarks:
The primitive blend will apply to all of the primitive drawn on the context, unless this is overridden with the compositeMode parameter on the method.
The primitive blend applies to the interior of any primitives drawn on the context. In the case of DrawImage, this will be implied by the image rectangle, offset and world transform.
If the primitive blend is anything other than then ClearType rendering will be turned off. If the application explicitly forces ClearType rendering in these modes, the drawing context will be placed in an error state. The will be thrown by either or .

Setting the unit mode will not affect the value returned by .

member.name: M:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.IDeviceContext.BeginDraw
member.summary: Initiates drawing on this render target.
member.remarks:
Drawing operations can only be issued between a BeginDraw and EndDraw call.
BeginDraw and EndDraw are used to indicate that a device context is in use by the Direct2D system. Different implementations of IDeviceContext might behave differently when BeginDraw is called. A bitmap device context may be locked between BeginDraw/EndDraw calls, a DXGI surface render target might be acquired on BeginDraw and released on EndDraw, while an may begin batching at BeginDraw and may present on EndDraw, for example.
The BeginDraw method must be called before rendering operations can be called, though state-setting and state-retrieval operations can be performed even outside of BeginDraw/EndDraw.
After BeginDraw is called, a device context will normally build up a batch of rendering commands, but defer processing of these commands until either an internal buffer is full, the Flush method is called, or until EndDraw is called. The EndDraw method causes any batched drawing operations to complete, and then returns to indicate success or throws an exception to indicate an error. The EndDraw method always succeeds: it should not be called twice even if a previous EndDraw resulted in an error.
If EndDraw is called without a matched call to BeginDraw, it returns an error indicating that BeginDraw must be called before EndDraw.
Calling BeginDraw twice on a render target puts the target into an error state where nothing further is drawn, and throws an appropriate exception when EndDraw is called.

member.name: M:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.IDeviceContext.EndDraw
member.summary: Ends drawing operations on the render target and indicates the current error state.
member.remarks: See for more information.

member.name: M:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.IDeviceContext.Flush
member.summary: Executes all pending drawing commands.
member.remarks:
This command does not flush the Direct3D device context that is associated with the render target.
Calling this method resets the error state of the device context.

member.name: M:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.IDeviceContext.PopAxisAlignedClip
member.summary: Removes the last axis-aligned clip from the render target. After this method is called, the clip is no longer applied to subsequent drawing operations.
member.remarks:
A PushAxisAlignedClip/PopAxisAlignedClip pair can occur around or within a PushLayer/PopLayer pair, but may not overlap. For example, a PushAxisAlignedClip, PushLayer, PopLayer, PopAxisAlignedClip sequence is valid, but a PushAxisAlignedClip, PushLayer, PopAxisAlignedClip, PopLayer sequence is not.
PopAxisAlignedClip must be called once for every call to PushAxisAlignedClip.
For an example, see How to Clip with an Axis-Aligned Clip Rectangle.

member.name: M:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.IDeviceContext.PopLayer
member.summary:
Stops redirecting drawing operations to the layer that is specified by the last call.
See Direct2D Layers Overview for more information.
member.remarks: A PopLayer must match a previous PushLayer call.

member.name: M:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.IDeviceContext.PushAxisAlignedClip(PaintDotNet.Rendering.RectFloat,PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.AntialiasMode)
member.summary: Specifies a rectangle to which all subsequent drawing operations are clipped.
member.param: The size and position of the clipping area, in device-independent pixels.

The antialiasing mode that is used to draw the edges of clip rects that have subpixel boundaries, and to blend the clip with the scene contents. The blending is performed once when the PopAxisAlignedClip method is called, and does not apply to each primitive within the layer.
member.remarks:
The clipRect is transformed by the current world transform set on the render target. After the transform is applied to the clipRect that is passed in, the axis-aligned bounding box for the clipRect is computed. For efficiency, the contents are clipped to this axis-aligned bounding box and not to the original clipRect that is passed in.
See PushAxisAlignedClip documentation for more details.

member.name: M:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.IDeviceContext.PushLayer(PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.LayerParameters@,PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.IDeviceLayer)
member.summary:
Push a layer onto the clip and layer stack of the device context. The layer will receive all subequent drawing operations until is called.
See Direct2D Layers Overview for more information.
member.param: The parameters that defines the layer.
The layer that receives subsequent drawing operations. It is recommended that you pass null.
member.remarks:
The PushLayer method allows a caller to begin redirecting rendering to a layer. All rendering operations are valid in a layer. The location of the layer is affected by the world transform set on the device context.
Each PushLayer must have a matching PopLayer call. If there are more PopLayer calls than PushLayer calls, the device context is placed into an error state. If Flush is called before all outstanding layers are popped, the render target is placed into an error state, and an exception is thrown. The error state can be cleared by a call to EndDraw.

member.summary: Creates a Direct2D bitmap by copying an .
member.param: The bitmap source to copy from.

A bitmap properties structure that specifies bitmap creation options. The pixel format must match the pixel format of the bitmap source, or the method will fails. To prevent a mismatch, you can pass null. If both dpiX and dpiY are 0, the default DPI of 96 will be used. The DPI information embedded in the bitmap source is ignored.
member.remarks:
The parameter is optional. When it is not specified, the created bitmap inherits the pixel format and alpha mode from . For a list of supported pixel formats and alpha modes, see Supported Pixel Formats and Alpha Modes.
When the bitmapProperties parameter is specified, the value in must either be or must match the pixel format of the .
When the is set to , the newly created bitmap inherits the alpha mode from . When the is set to , , or , this forces the newly created bitmap to use the specified alpha mode.
Before Direct2D can load from a bitmap source, it must be converted to a supported pixel format and alpha mode. For a list of supported pixel formats and alpha modes, see Supported Pixel Formats and Alpha Modes.

member.name: M:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.IDeviceContext.CreateCompatibleDeviceContext(System.Nullable{PaintDotNet.Rendering.SizeFloat},System.Nullable{PaintDotNet.Rendering.SizeInt32},System.Nullable{PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.DevicePixelFormat},PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.CompatibleDeviceContextOptions)
member.summary: Creates a bitmap device context for use during intermediate offscreen drawing that is compatible with the current render target.
member.param: The desired size of the new device context (in device-independent pixels), if it should be different from the original device context. For more info, see the Remarks section.
The desired size of the new device context in pixels if it should be different from the original device context. For more information, see the Remarks section.

The desired pixel format and alpha mode of the new device context. If the pixel format is set to , the new device context uses the same pixel format as the original device context. If the alpha mode is , the alpha mode of the new device context defaults to . For information about supported pixel formats, see Supported Pixel Formats and Alpha Modes.
A value that specifies whether the new render target must be compatible with GDI.
member.remarks:
The pixel size and DPI of the new render target can be altered by specifying values for desiredSize or desiredPixelSize.
If desiredSize is specified but desiredPixelSize is not, the pixel size is computed from the desired size using the parent target DPI. If the desiredSize maps to a integer-pixel size, the DPI of the compatible render target is the same as the DPI of the parent target. If desiredSize maps to a fractional-pixel size, the pixel size is rounded up to the nearest integer and the DPI for the compatible device context is slightly higher than the DPI of the parent device context. In all cases, the coordinate (desiredSize.width, desiredSize.height) maps to the lower-right corner of the compatible device context.
If the desiredPixelSize is specified and desiredSize is not, the DPI of the new render target is the same as the original device context.
If both desiredSize and desiredPixelSize are specified, the DPI of the new device context is computed to account for the difference in scale.
If neither desiredSize nor desiredPixelSize is specified, the new render target size and DPI match the original device context.

member.name: M:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.IDeviceContext.CreateGradientStopCollection(System.ReadOnlySpan{PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.GradientStop},PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.GradientStopGamma,PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.ExtendMode)
member.summary: Creates an from the specified array of structures.
member.param: The array of structures.
The space in which color interpolation between the gradient stops is performed.
The behavior of the gradient outside the [0,1] normalized range.

member.summary: Creates a gradient stop collection, enabling the gradient to contain color channels with values outside of [0,1] and also enabling rendering to a high-color render target with interpolation in sRGB space.
member.param: An array of color values and offsets.
Specifies both the input color space and the space in which the color interpolation occurs.
The color space that colors will be converted to after interpolation occurs.
The precision of the texture used to hold interpolated values.
Defines how colors outside of the range defined by the stop collection are determined.
Defines how colors are interpolated. is the default, see Remarks for more info.
member.remarks:
This method linearly interpolates between the color stops. An optional color space conversion is applied post-interpolation. Whether and how this gamma conversion is applied is determined by the pre- and post-interpolation. This method will fail if the device context does not support the requested buffer precision.
In order to get the desired result, you need to ensure that the inputs are specified in the correct color space.
You must always specify colors in straight alpha, regardless of interpolation mode being premultiplied or straight. The interpolation mode only affects the interpolated values. Likewise, the stops returned by will always have straight alpha.
If you specify , then all stops are premultiplied before interpolation, and then un-premultiplied before color conversion.
See ID2D1DeviceContext::CreateGradientStopCollection method for a table showing the interpolation behavior with respect to the color space options.

member.name: M:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.IDeviceContext.CreateSharedBitmap(PaintDotNet.Imaging.IBitmapLock,System.Nullable{PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.SharedBitmapProperties}@)
member.summary: Creates an whose data is shared (not copied) with an .
member.param: The that contains the data to share with the new device bitmap.

The pixel format and DPI of the bitmap to create. The portion of the pixel format must match the DxgiFormat of the data or the method will fail, but the alpha modes don't have to match. To prevent a mismatch, you can pass null. The DPI settings do not have to match those of data. If both dpiX and dpiY are 0.0f, the DPI of the device context is used.
member.remarks:
The CreateSharedBitmap method is useful for efficiently reusing bitmap data when using a software device context.
An stores the content of a bitmap and shields it from simultaneous accesses. By passing an IBitmapLock to the CreateSharedBitmap method, you can create an that points to the bitmap data already stored in the IBitmapLock.
To use an IBitmapLock with the CreateSharedBitmap method, the device context must be using software rendering. To check whether a device context uses software rendering, use the method or the IsSoftwareContext extension method.

member.name: M:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.IDeviceContext.CreateSharedBitmap(PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.IDeviceBitmap,System.Nullable{PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.SharedBitmapProperties}@)
member.summary: Creates an whose data is shared (not copied) with another .
member.param: The that contains the data to share with the new device bitmap.

The pixel format and DPI of the bitmap to create. The portion of the pixel format must match the DxgiFormat of the data or the method will fail, but the alpha modes don't have to match. To prevent a mismatch, you can pass null. The DPI settings do not have to match those of data. If both dpiX and dpiY are 0.0f, the DPI of the device context is used.
member.remarks:
By passing an created by a device context that is resource-compatible, you can share a bitmap with that render target; both the original and the new created by this method will point to the same bitmap data (it is not copied). For more information about when device context resources can be shared, see the Sharing Render Target Resources section of the Resources Overview.
You may also use this method to reinterpret the data of an existing bitmap and specify a new DPI or alpha mode. For example, in the case of a bitmap atlas, an may contain multiple sub-images, each of which should be rendered with a different (either or ). You could use the CreateSharedBitmap method to reinterpret the bitmap using the desired alpha mode without having to load a separate copy of the bitmap into memory.

member.summary: Retrieves an image of the color bitmap glyph from the color glyph cache. If the cache does not already contain the requested resource, it will be created. This method may be used to extend the lifetime of a glyph image even after it is evicted from the color glyph cache.
member.param: The format for the glyph image. If there is no image data in the requested format for the requested glyph, this method will throw an exception.
The origin for the glyph.
Reference to a font face which contains font face type, appropriate file references, face identification data and various font data such as metrics, names and glyph outlines.
The specified font size affects the choice of which bitmap to use from the font. It also affects the output GlyphTransform, causing it to properly scale the glyph.
Index of the glyph.

If true, specifies that glyphs are rotated 90 degrees to the left and vertical metrics are used. Vertical writing is achieved by specifying isSideways as true and rotating the entire run 90 degrees to the right via a rotate transform.

The transform to apply to the image. This input transform affects the choice of which bitmap to use from the font. It is also factored into the output glyphTransform. If null, the identity matrix will be used.
Dots per inch.

Output transform, which transforms from the glyph's space to the same output space as the worldTransform. This includes the input glyphOrigin, the glyph's offset from the glyphOrigin, and any other required transformations.

member.summary: Retrieves an image of the SVG glyph from the color glyph cache. If the cache does not already contain the requested resource, it will be created. This method may be used to extend the lifetime of a glyph image even after it is evicted from the color glyph cache.
member.param: Origin of the glyph.
Reference to a font face which contains font face type, appropriate file references, face identification data and various font data such as metrics, names and glyph outlines.
The specified font size affects the output glyphTransform, causing it to properly scale the glyph.
Index of the glyph to retrieve.

If true, specifies that glyphs are rotated 90 degrees to the left and vertical metrics are used. Vertical writing is achieved by specifying isSideways as true and rotating the entire run 90 degrees to the right via a rotate transform.
The transform to apply to the image. If null, the identity matrix will be used.
Describes how the area is painted.
The values for context-fill, context-stroke, and context-value that are used when rendering SVG glyphs.
The index used to select a color palette within a color font. Note that this is not the same as the paletteIndex in the ColorGlyphRun struct, which is not relevant for SVG glyphs.

Output transform, which transforms from the glyph's space to the same output space as the worldTransform. This includes the input glyphOrigin, the glyph's offset from the glyphOrigin, and any other required transformations.

member.name: M:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.IDeviceContext.Clear(System.Nullable{PaintDotNet.Imaging.ColorRgba128Float}@)
member.summary: Clears the drawing area to the specified color.
member.param: The color to which the drawing area is cleared. If null, the color will be transparent black.
member.remarks:
Direct2D interprets the clearColor as straight alpha (not premultiplied). If the render target's alpha mode is , the alpha channel of clearColor is ignored and replaced with 1.0f (fully opaque)
If the render target has an active clip (specified by PushAxisAlignedClip), the clear command is applied only to the area within the clip region.
If null is used for the clearColor, and the current target is an , the bounds as returned by and will be an empty rectangle. Using non-null will result in the rectangle being infinite.

member.name: M:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.IDeviceContext.BlendImage(PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.IDeviceImage,PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.BlendMode,System.Nullable{PaintDotNet.Rendering.Point2Float},System.Nullable{PaintDotNet.Rendering.RectFloat}@,PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.InterpolationMode)

member.param: The image to be drawn to the device context.
The blend mode to be used. See and Direct2D Blend effect for more info.

The offset in the destination space that the image will be rendered to. The entire logical extent of the image will be rendered to the corresponding destination. If not specified, the destination origin will be (0, 0). The top-left corner of the image will be mapped to the target offset. This will not necessarily be the origin. The default value is null.
The corresponding rectangle in the image space will be mapped to the given origins when processing the image. The default value is null.
The interpolation mode that will be used to scale the image if necessary. The default value is .

member.name: M:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.IDeviceContext.DrawBitmap(PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.IDeviceBitmap,System.Nullable{PaintDotNet.Rendering.RectFloat}@,System.Single,PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.InterpolationMode,System.Nullable{PaintDotNet.Rendering.RectFloat}@,System.Nullable{PaintDotNet.Rendering.Matrix4x4Float}@)
member.summary: Draws a bitmap to the render target.
member.param: The bitmap to draw.
The destination rectangle. The default is the size of the bitmap and the location is the upper left corner of the render target.
The opacity of the bitmap.
The interpolation mode to use if the bitmap is scaled or rotated by the drawing operation.
An optional source rectangle.
An optional perspective transform.
member.remarks:
The destinationRectangle parameter defines the rectangle in the target where the bitmap will appear (in device-independent pixels (DIPs)). This is affected by the currently set transform and the perspective transform, if set. If null is specified, then the destination rectangle is (left=0, top=0, right = width(sourceRectangle), bottom = height(sourceRectangle)).
The srcRect parameter defines the sub-rectangle of the source bitmap (in DIPs). DrawBitmap will clip this rectangle to the size of the source bitmap, thus making it impossible to sample outside of the bitmap. If null is specified, then the source rectangle is taken to be the size of the source bitmap.
If you specify perspectiveTransform it is applied to the rect in addition to the transform set on the render target.

member.name: M:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.IDeviceContext.DrawGeometryRealization(PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.IGeometryRealization,PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.IDeviceBrush)
member.summary: Renders a given geometry realization to the target with the specified brush.
member.param: The geometry realization to be rendered.
The brush to render the realization with.
member.remarks:
This method respects all currently set state (transform, DPI, unit mode, target image, clips, layers); however, artifacts such as faceting may appear when rendering the realizations with a large effective scale (either via the transform or the DPI). Callers should create their realizations with an appropriate flattening tolerance using either or to compensate for this.
Additionally, callers should be aware of the safe render bounds when creating geometry realizations. If a geometry extends outside of [-524287, 524287] DIPs in either the X- or the Y- direction in its original (pre-transform) coordinate space, then it may be clipped to those bounds when it is realized. This clipping will be visible even if the realization is subsequently transformed to fit within the safe render bounds.

member.summary: Draws an image to the device context. The image can be any type of , including an , , or .
member.param: The image to be drawn to the device context.

The offset in the destination space that the image will be rendered to. The entire logical extent of the image will be rendered to the corresponding destination. If not specified, the destination origin will be (0, 0). The top-left corner of the image will be mapped to the target offset. This will not necessarily be the origin. This default value is null.
The corresponding rectangle in the image space will be mapped to the given origins when processing the image. This default value is null.
The interpolation mode that will be used to scale the image if necessary.
The composite mode that will be applied to the limits of the currently selected clip. The default value is .
member.remarks:
If interpolationMode is , different scalers will be used depending on the scale factor implied by the world transform.
Any invalid rectangles accumulated on any effect that is drawn by this call will be discarded regardless of which portion of the image rectangle is drawn.
If compositeMode is , DrawImage will use the currently selected primitive blend specified by .
If compositeMode is not , the image will be extended to transparent up to the current axis-aligned clip.
If there is an image rectangle and a world transform, this is equivalent to inserting a clip effect to represent the image rectangle and a 2D affine transform to take into account the world transform.

The opacity mask to apply to the geometry, or null for no opacity mask. If an opacity mask (the opacityBrush parameter) is specified, brush must be an that has its x- and y-extend modes set to . For more information, see the Remarks section.
member.remarks:
If the opacityBrush parameter is not null, the alpha value of each pixel of the mapped opacityBrush is used to determine the resulting opacity of each corresponding pixel of the geometry. member.remarks:
The image bounds don't include multiplication by the world transform. They do reflect the current DPI, unit mode, and interpolation mode of the context.
To get the bounds that include the world transform, use .
The returned bounds reflect which pixels would be impacted by calling with a target offset of (0,0) and an identity world transform matrix. They do not reflect the current clip rectangle set on the device context or the extent of the context's current target image.

member.name: M:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.IDeviceContext.InvalidateEffectInputRectangle(PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.IDeviceEffect,System.Int32,PaintDotNet.Rendering.RectFloat)
member.summary:
This indicates that a portion of an effect's input is invalid. This method can be called many times.
You can use this method to propagate invalid rectangles through an effect graph. You can query Direct2D using the method.
NOTE: Direct2D does not automatically use these invalid rectangles to reduce the region of an effect that is rendered.
You can also use this method to invalidate caches that have accumulated while rendering effects that have the Cached property set to true.
member.param: The effect to invalidate.
The input index.
The rect to invalidate.

member.name: M:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.IDeviceContext.GetEffectInvalidRectangles(PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.IDeviceEffect)
member.summary: Gets the invalid rectangles that have accumulated since the last time the effect was drawn and was then called on the device context.
member.param: The effect to get the invalid rectangles from.
member.returns: The invalid rectangles for the effect.
member.remarks:
Note: Direct2D does not automatically use these invalid rectangles to reduce the region of an effect that is rendered.
You can use the method to specify invalidated rectangles for Direct2D to propagate through an effect graph.

member.name: M:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.IDeviceContext.GetEffectRequiredInputRectangles(PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.IDeviceEffect,System.Nullable{PaintDotNet.Rendering.RectFloat}@,System.ReadOnlySpan{PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.EffectInputDescription})
member.summary: Returns the input rectangles that are required to be supplied by the caller to produce the given output rectangle.
member.param: The effect whose output is being rendered.
The portion of the output image whose inputs are being inspected.
A list of the inputs whose rectangles are being queried.
member.remarks: The caller should be very careful not to place a reliance on the required input rectangles returned. Small changes for correctness to an effect's behavior can result in different rectangles being returned. In addition, different kinds of optimization applied inside the render can also influence the result.

member.summary:
Provides factory methods and other state management for effect and transform authors.

member.remarks: This interface is passed to an effect implementation through the method. In order to prevent applications casually gaining access to this interface, and to separate reference counts between the public and private interfaces, it is not possible to call CreateRef() between the and the . Each call to will be provided a different object. This interface tracks resource allocations for the effect. When the effect is released, the corresponding allocations will also be released.

member.summary:
The renderer calls this method to provide the effect implementation with a way to specify its transform graph and transform graph changes.
The renderer calls this method when:
* When the effect is first initialized.
* If the number of inputs to the effect changes.

member.param: The graph to which the effect describes its transform topology.
member.remarks:
You usually don't need to implement this method. Instead, perform one-time initialization tasks in , and then update or create the effect graph in .
If the transformGraph is stored by the implementation of this interface, a new ref must be created with the CreateRef() extension method. The object "refs" passed to this method will be disposed once it returns, but creating a new ref extends the lifetime of the underlying object.

member.summary:
Represents a geometry resource and defines a set of helper methods for manipulating and measuring geometric shapes. Interfaces that inherit from IGeometry define specific shapes.
ID2D1Geometry

member.name: M:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.IGeometry.CompareWithGeometry(PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.IGeometry,System.Nullable{PaintDotNet.Rendering.Matrix3x2Float}@,System.Nullable{System.Single})
member.summary: Describes the intersection between this geometry and the specified geometry. The comparison is performed by using the specified flattening tolerance.
member.param: The geometry to test.
The transform to apply to inputGeometry, or null for no transform.

The maximum error allowed when constructing a polygonal approximation of the geometry, or null to use FlatteningTolerance.Default. No point in the polygonal representation will diverge from the original geometry by more than the flattening tolerance. Smaller values produce more accurate results but cause slower execution.
member.returns: A value describing how this geometry is related to inputGeometry.
member.remarks: When interpreting the returned relation value, it is important to remember that a result of GeometryRelation.IsContained means that this geometry is contained inside inputGeometry, not that this geometry contains inputGeometry.

member.name: M:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.IGeometry.ComputeArea(System.Nullable{PaintDotNet.Rendering.Matrix3x2Float}@,System.Nullable{System.Single})
member.summary: Computes the area of the geometry after it has been transformed by the specified matrix and flattened using the specified tolerance.
member.param: The transform to apply to this geometry before computing its area, or null for no transform.

The maximum error allowed when constructing a polygonal approximation of the geometry, or null to use FlatteningTolerance.Default. No point in the polygonal representation will diverge from the original geometry by more than the flattening tolerance. Smaller values produce more accurate results but cause slower execution.
member.returns: The area of the transformed, flattened version of this geometry.

member.name: M:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.IGeometry.ComputeLength(System.Nullable{PaintDotNet.Rendering.Matrix3x2Float}@,System.Nullable{System.Single})
member.summary: Calculates the length of the geometry as though each segment were unrolled into a line.
member.param: The transform to apply to the geometry before calculating its length, or null for no transform.

The maximum error allowed when constructing a polygonal approximation of the geometry, or null to use FlatteningTolerance.Default. No point in the polygonal representation will diverge from the original geometry by more than the flattening tolerance. Smaller values produce more accurate results but cause slower execution.
member.returns: Returns the length of the geometry. For closed geometries, the length includes an implicit closing segment.

member.name: M:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.IGeometry.ComputePointAtLength(System.Single,System.Nullable{PaintDotNet.Rendering.Matrix3x2Float}@,System.Nullable{System.Single},PaintDotNet.Rendering.Vector2Float@)
member.summary: Calculates the point and tangent vector at the specified distance along the geometry after it has been transformed by the specified matrix and flattened using the specified tolerance.
member.param: The distance along the geometry of the point and tangent to find. If this distance is less than 0, this method calculates the first point in the geometry. If this distance is greater than the length of the geometry, this method calculates the last point in the geometry.
The transform to apply to the geometry before calculating the specified point and tangent, or null for no transform.

The maximum error allowed when constructing a polygonal approximation of the geometry, or null to use FlatteningTolerance.Default. No point in the polygonal representation will diverge from the original geometry by more than the flattening tolerance. Smaller values produce more accurate results but cause slower execution.
On return, contains the tangent vector at the specified distance along the geometry. If the geometry is empty, this vector contains NaN as its x and y values.
member.returns: Returns the location at the specified distance along the geometry. If the geometry is empty, this point contains NaN as its x and y values.

member.name: M:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.IGeometry.FillContainsPoint(PaintDotNet.Rendering.Point2Float,System.Nullable{PaintDotNet.Rendering.Matrix3x2Float}@,System.Nullable{System.Single})
member.summary: Indicates whether the area filled by the geometry would contain the specified point given the specified flattening tolerance.
member.param: The point to test.
The transform to apply to the geometry prior to testing for containment, or null for no transform.

The numeric accuracy with which the precise geometric path and path intersection is calculated. Points missing the fill by less than the tolerance are still considered inside. Smaller values produce more accurate results but cause slower execution. If this value is null, FlatteningTolerance.Default will be used.
member.returns: true if the area filled by the geometry contains point; otherwise, false.

members.member:
Retrieves the bounds of the geometry.
The transform to apply to this geometry before calculating its bounds, or null for no transform. The bounds of the geometry. This method will return RectFloat.Empty if the geometry is empty.
This method does not include hollow regions. Use GetWidenedBounds() with a zero strokeWidth if you need to include hollow regions.
(Regarding the remarks, see also: PaintDotNet.UI.Media.Geometry.get_Bounds)

The maximum error allowed when constructing a polygonal approximation of the geometry, or null to use FlatteningTolerance.Default. No point in the polygonal representation will diverge from the original geometry by more than the flattening tolerance. Smaller values produce more accurate results but cause slower execution.

member.name: M:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.IGeometry.Simplify(PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.ISimplifiedGeometrySink,PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.GeometrySimplificationOption,System.Nullable{PaintDotNet.Rendering.Matrix3x2Float}@,System.Nullable{System.Single})
member.summary: Creates a simplified version of the geometry that contains only lines and (optionally) cubic Bezier curves and writes the result to an ISimplifiedGeometrySink.
member.param: The ISimplifiedGeometrySink to which the simplified geometry is appended.
A value that specifies whether the simplified geometry should contain curves.
The transform to apply to the simplified geometry, or null for no transform.

The maximum error allowed when constructing a polygonal approximation of the geometry, or null to use FlatteningTolerance.Default. No point in the polygonal representation will diverge from the original geometry by more than the flattening tolerance. Smaller values produce more accurate results but cause slower execution.
member.remarks: Other graphics frameworks may call this "flattening" (e.g. Windows Presentation Foundation).

The maximum error allowed when constructing a polygonal approximation of the geometry, or null to use FlatteningTolerance.Default. member.summary:
Creates a 3D lookup table for mapping a 3-channel input to a 3-channel output. The table data must be provided in 4-channel format.
ID2D1DeviceContext2::CreateLookupTable3D()
ID2D1EffectContext1::CreateLookupTable3D()
member.param: Precision of the input lookup table data.
The number of elements in the X dimension, which corresponds to the blue channel.
The number of elements, or rows, in the Y dimension, which corresponds to the green channel.
The number of elements, or planes, in the Z dimension, which corresponds to the red channel.
Buffer holding the lookup table data. This total byte size of the data buffer must be appropriate for the given precision and extents.
The number of bytes from one row (X dimension) of LUT data to the next.
The number of bytes from one LUT data plane (X and Y dimensions) to the next.
member.remarks: The maximum extent in any direction is 256, which means that a 256x256x256 table using 32-bits per component will consume 64MB. Because lookup uses linear interpolation, much smaller tables will usually give good results.

member.summary: Indicates the image source should release its reference to the WIC bitmap source after it has initialized. By default, the image source retains a reference to the WIC bitmap source for the lifetime of the object to enable quality and speed optimizations for printing. This option disables that optimization.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.ImageSourceLoadingOptions.CacheOnDemand
member.summary: Indicates the image source should only populate subregions of the image cache on-demand. You can control this behavior using the EnsureCached and TrimCache methods. This options provides the ability to improve memory usage by only keeping needed portions of the image in memory. This option requires that the image source has a reference to the WIC bitmap source, and is incompatible with the ReleaseSource option.

member.name: T:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.InterpolationMode
member.summary: This is used to specify the quality of image scaling with .

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.InterpolationMode.NearestNeighbor
member.summary: Samples the nearest single point and uses that. This mode uses less processing time, but outputs the lowest quality image.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.InterpolationMode.Linear
member.summary: Uses a four point sample and linear interpolation. This mode uses more processing time than the nearest neighbor mode, but outputs a higher quality image.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.InterpolationMode.Cubic
member.summary: Uses a 16 sample cubic kernel for interpolation. This mode uses the most processing time, but outputs a higher quality image.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.InterpolationMode.MultisampleLinear
member.summary: Uses 4 linear samples within a single pixel for good edge anti-aliasing. This mode is good for scaling down by small amounts on images with few pixels.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.InterpolationMode.Anisotropic
member.summary: Uses anisotropic filtering to sample a pattern according to the transformed shape of the bitmap.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.InterpolationMode.HighQualityCubic
member.summary: Uses a variable size high quality cubic kernel to perform a pre-downscale of the image if downscaling is involved in the transform matrix. Then uses the cubic interpolation mode for the final output.

member.name: T:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.InterpolationModeDefinition
member.summary: Defines the standard constant values used to specify interpolation modes. All Direct2D InterpolationMode enums (e.g. ) use these values.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.InterpolationModeDefinition.Linear

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.InterpolationModeDefinition.Fant
member.summary: Uses the WIC Fant interpolation, the same as the IWICBitmapScaler interface. Doesn't generate a mipmap.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.InterpolationModeDefinition.MipmapLinear
member.summary: Generates mipmap chain in system memory using bilinear interpolation. For each mipmap the effect scales to the nearest multiple of 0.5 using bilinear interpolation and then scales the remaining amount using linear interpolation.

member.name: T:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.ISimplifiedGeometrySink
member.summary:
Describes a geometric path that does not contain quadratic bezier curves or arcs.
See ID2D1SimplifiedGeometrySink for more information.
member.remarks:
An implementation of this interface is provided when using .
To implement this yourself, such as to capture the data provided from various methods on , create a class that derives from and that also derives from this interface.
For better performance, implement the interface, which derives from this interface.

member.name: M:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.ISimplifiedGeometrySink.AddBeziers(System.ReadOnlySpan{PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.BezierSegment})
member.summary: Creates a sequence of cubic Bezier curves and adds them to the geometry sink.
member.param: A pointer to an array of Bezier segments that describes the Bezier curves to create. A curve is drawn from the geometry sink's current point (the end point of the last segment drawn or the location specified by ) to the end point of the first Bezier segment in the array. If the array contains additional Bezier segments, each subsequent Bezier segment uses the end point of the preceding Bezier segment as its start point.

member.name: M:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.ISimplifiedGeometrySink.AddLines(System.ReadOnlySpan{PaintDotNet.Rendering.Point2Float})
member.summary: Creates a sequence of lines using the specified points and adds them to the geometry sink.
member.param: A pointer to an array of one or more points that describe the lines to draw. A line is drawn from the geometry sink's current point (the end point of the last segment drawn or the location specified by ) to the first point in the array. if the array contains additional points, a line is drawn from the first point to the second point in the array, from the second point to the third point, and so on.

member.name: M:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.ISimplifiedGeometrySink.BeginFigure(PaintDotNet.Rendering.Point2Float,PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.FigureBegin)
member.summary: Starts a new figure at the specified point.
member.param: The point at which to begin the new figure.
Whether the new figure should be hollow or filled.
member.remarks: If this method is called while a figure is currently in progress, the interface is invalidated and all future methods will fail.

member.name: M:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.ISimplifiedGeometrySink.Close
member.summary: Closes the geometry sink, indicates whether it is in an error state, and resets the sink's error state.
member.remarks:
Do not close the geometry sink while a figure is still in progress; doing so puts the geometry sink in an error state. For the close operation to be successful, there must be one call for each call to
After calling this method, the geometry sink might not be usable. Direct2D implementations of this interface do not allow the geometry sink to be modified after it is closed, but other implementations might not impose this restriction.

member.name: M:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.ISimplifiedGeometrySink.EndFigure(PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.FigureEnd)
member.summary: Ends the current figure; optionally, closes it.
member.param: A value that indicates whether the current figure is closed. If the figure is closed, a line is drawn between the current point and the start point specified by .

member.name: M:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.ISimplifiedGeometrySink.SetFillMode(PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.FillMode)
member.summary: Specifies the method used to determine which points are inside the geometry described by this geometry sink and which points are outside.
member.param: The method used to determine whether a given point is part of the geometry.
member.remarks: The fill mode defaults to . To set the fill mode, call before the first call to . Not doing so will put the geometry sink into an error state.

member.remarks: After this method is called, the specified segment flags are applied to each segment subsequently added to the sink. The segment flags are applied to every additional segment until this method is called again and a different set of segment flags is specified.
