member.name: T:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.ISpriteBatch
member.summary:
Represents a single group of sprites with their associated drawing properties.
ID2D1SpriteBatch
member.remarks: Sprites are a way for apps to draw a large number of images very efficiently. They are commonly used to render characters and backgrounds in 2D games, or to render particle systems such as smoke and flames. If your app has performance demands and needs to draw hundreds or thousands of images every frame, then consider taking advantage of sprite batches and the fine-grained control they offer, instead of the general-purpose DrawImage method.

member.name: P:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.ISpriteBatch.SpriteCount
member.summary: Gets the number of sprites in this sprite batch.

member.name: M:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.ISpriteBatch.Clear
member.summary: Removes all sprites from this sprite batch.

member.name: M:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.ISpriteBatch.AddSprites(System.Int32,System.ReadOnlySpan{PaintDotNet.Rendering.RectFloat},System.ReadOnlySpan{PaintDotNet.Rendering.RectInt32},System.ReadOnlySpan{PaintDotNet.Imaging.ColorRgba128Float},System.ReadOnlySpan{PaintDotNet.Rendering.Matrix3x2Float})
member.summary: Adds the given sprites to the end of this sprite batch. You may use a 1-length span for any of the properties to use the same value for each sprite. You may use a 0-length span (using the C# `default` keyword, or ReadOnlySpan<T>.Empty) for sourceRectangles, colors, or transforms in order to use the default policy associated with that property. This can reduce memory usage and increase performance.
member.param: The number of sprites to be added.
The destination rectangles specifying where to draw the sprites.

The source rectangles specifying the regions of the source bitmap to draw as sprites. Direct2D will use the entire source bitmap for sprites that are assigned a null value or if RectInt32.LogicallyInfinite is used. If this span is empty, Direct2D will use the entire source bitmap for all of the added sprites.

The colors to apply to each sprite. The output color is the result of component-wise multiplication of the source bitmap color and the provided color. The output color is not clamped. Direct2D will not change the color of sprites that are assigned a null value. If this span is empty, then Direct2D will not change the color of any of the added sprites.

The transforms to apply to each sprite's destination recangle. Direct2D will not transform the destination rectangle of any sprites that are assigned a null value. If this span is empty then Direct2D will not transform the destination rectangle of any of the added sprites.
member.remarks: Always use an empty span for properties you do not wish to use. This allows Direct2D to avoid storing values for those properties and to skip their handling entirely, which improves drawing speed. For example, suppose you have a batch of 500 sprites, and you do not wish to transform any of their destination rectangles. Rather than passing an array of identity matrices, simply omit the transforms parameter. This allows Direct2D to avoid storing any transforms and will yield the fastest drawing performance. On the other hand, if any sprite in the batch has any value set for a property, then internally Direct2D must allocate space for that property array and assign every sprite a value for that property (even if itâ€™s just the default value).

member.name: M:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.ISpriteBatch.GetSprites(System.Int32,System.Span{PaintDotNet.Rendering.RectFloat},System.Span{PaintDotNet.Rendering.RectInt32},System.Span{PaintDotNet.Imaging.ColorRgba128Float},System.Span{PaintDotNet.Rendering.Matrix3x2Float})
member.summary: Retrieves the specified subset of sprites from this sprite batch. For the best performance, use an empty Span (using the C# default keyword, or Span<T>.Empty) for properties that you do not need to retrieve.
member.param: The index of the first sprite in this sprite batch to retrieve.
When this method returns, contains the destination rectangles for the retrieved sprites.
When this method returns, contains the source rectangles for the retrieved sprites. RectInt32.LogicallyInfinite is returned for any sprites that were not assigned a source rectangle.
When this method returns, contains the colors to be applied to the retrieved sprites. The color { 1, 1, 1, 1 } (opaque white) is returned for any sprites that were not assigned a color.
When this method returns, contains the transforms to be applied to the retrived sprites. The identity matrix is returned for any sprites that were not assigned a transform.

member.name: M:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.ISpriteBatch.SetSprites(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.ReadOnlySpan{PaintDotNet.Rendering.RectFloat},System.ReadOnlySpan{PaintDotNet.Rendering.RectInt32},System.ReadOnlySpan{PaintDotNet.Imaging.ColorRgba128Float},System.ReadOnlySpan{PaintDotNet.Rendering.Matrix3x2Float})
member.summary: Updates the properties of the specified sprites in the sprite batch. Providing an empty span for any property will leave that property unmodified for the sprites. Providing a 1-length span for any property will use the same value for all of the sprites.

member.name: T:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.ISvgPathData
member.summary:
Interface describing SVG path data. Path data can be set as the 'd' attribute on a 'path' element. The path data set is factored into two arrays. The segment data array stores all numbers and the commands array stores the set of commands. Unlike the string data set in the d attribute, each command in this representation uses a fixed number of elements in the segment data array. Therefore, the path 'M 0,0 100,0 0,100 Z' is represented as: 'M0,0 L100,0 L0,100 Z'. This is split into two arrays, with the segment data containing '0,0 100,0 0,100', and the commands containing 'M L L Z'.
ID2D1SvgPathData

member.name: T:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.ITransform
member.summary:
Represents the base interface for all of the transforms implemented by the transform author.
ID2D1Transform

member.name: M:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.ITransform.MapInputRectsToOutputRect(System.ReadOnlySpan{PaintDotNet.Rendering.RectInt32},System.ReadOnlySpan{PaintDotNet.Rendering.RectInt32},PaintDotNet.Rendering.RectInt32@,PaintDotNet.Rendering.RectInt32@)
member.summary: Performs the inverse mapping to MapOutputRectToInputRects.
member.remarks: The transform implementation must ensure that any pixel shader or software callback implementation it provides honors this calculation. Unlike the MapOutputRectToInputRects and MapInvalidRect functions, this method is explicitly called by the renderer at a determined place in its rendering algorithm. The transform implementation may change its state based on the input rectangles and use this information to control its rendering information. This method is always called before the MapInvalidRect and MapOutputRectToInputRects methods of the transform.
member.param: An array of input rectangles to be mapped to the output rectangle. The inputRects parameter is always equal to the input bounds.
An array of input rectangles to be mapped to the opaque output rectangle.
The output rectangle that maps to the corresponding input rectangle.
The output rectangle that maps to the corresponding opaque input rectangle. Set this to RectInt32.Zero to indicate that the whole output region may have transparency.

member.name: M:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.ITransform.MapOutputRectToInputRects(PaintDotNet.Rendering.RectInt32,System.Span{PaintDotNet.Rendering.RectInt32})
member.summary: Allows a transform to state how it would map a rectangle requested on its output to a set of sample rectangles on its input.
member.remarks: The transform implementation must ensure that any pixel shader or software callback implementation it provides honors this calculation. The transform implementation must regard this method as purely functional. It can base the mapped input and output rectangles on its current state as specified by the encapsulating effect properties. However, it must not change its own state in response to this method being invoked. The Direct2D renderer implementation reserves the right to call this method at any time and in any sequence.
member.param: The output rectangle from which the inputs must be mapped.
The corresponding set of inputs. The inputs will directly correspond to the transform inputs.

member.name: M:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.ITransform.MapInvalidRect(System.Int32,PaintDotNet.Rendering.RectInt32,PaintDotNet.Rendering.RectInt32@)
member.summary: Sets the input rectangles for this rendering pass into the transform.
member.remarks: The transform implementation must regard MapInvalidRect as purely functional. The transform implementation can base the mapped input rectangle on the transform implementation's current state as specified by the encapsulating effect properties. But the transform implementation can't change its own state in response to a call to MapInvalidRect. Direct2D can call this method at any time and in any sequence following a call to the MapInputRectsToOutputRect method.
member.param: The index of the input rectangle.
The invalid input rectangle.
The output rectangle to which the input rectangle must be mapped.

member.name: M:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.LookupTable3DFactoryExtensions.CreateLookupTable3D``1(PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.ILookupTable3DFactory,PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.BufferPrecision,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.ReadOnlySpan{``0})
member.summary:
Creates a 3D lookup table for mapping a 3-channel input to a 3-channel output. The table data must be provided in 4-channel format.
ID2D1DeviceContext2::CreateLookupTable3D()
ID2D1EffectContext1::CreateLookupTable3D()
member.param: The factory to use.
Precision of the input lookup table data.
The number of elements in the X dimension, which corresponds to the blue channel.
The number of elements, or rows, in the Y dimension, which corresponds to the green channel.
The number of elements, or planes, in the Z dimension, which corresponds to the red channel.
Buffer holding the lookup table data. This total byte size of the buffer must be appropriate for the given precision and extents.
member.remarks:
The maximum extent in any direction is 256, which means that a 256x256x256 table using 32-bits per component will consume 64MB. Because lookup uses linear interpolation, much smaller tables will usually give good results.
T may be any unmanaged type, but it is recommended to use a type that is appropriate for the given precision and to simplify working with it. For example:
For or , use . You can also use with 4 times as many elements.
For , use . You can also use with 4 times as many elements.
For , use with each lookup table entry spanning 4 elements.
For , use , , or . You can also use with 4 times as many elements.
The total number of elements when using a 4-component data type must be extentX * extentY * extentZ.
If using , , , or , the number of elements must be 4 * extentX * extentY * extentZ.
The total byte size of the data buffer must be appropriate for the given precision and extents. The elements of type T are bitwise reinterpreted; they are neither converted nor cast.

member.summary: The segment is joined as specified by the interface, and it is stroked.

member.summary: The segment is not stroked.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.PathSegmentOptions.ForceRoundLineJoin
member.summary: The segment is always joined with the one preceding it using a round line join, regardless of which enumeration is specified by the interface. If this segment is the first segment and the figure is closed, a round line join is used to connect the closing segment with the first segment. If the figure is not closed, this setting has no effect on the first segment of the figure. If is called just before , the join between the closing segment and the last explicitly specified segment is affected.

member.name: T:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.PerspectiveTransform3DInterpolationMode
member.summary:
The interpolation mode the PerspectiveTransform3D effect uses on the image. There are 5 scale modes that range in quality and speed.
D2D1_3DPERSPECTIVETRANSFORM_INTERPOLATION_MODE

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.PerspectiveTransform3DInterpolationMode.NearestNeighbor
member.summary: Samples the nearest single point and uses that. This mode uses less processing time, but outputs the lowest quality image.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.PerspectiveTransform3DInterpolationMode.Linear
member.summary: Uses a four point sample and linear interpolation. This mode uses more processing time than the nearest neighbor mode, but outputs a higher quality image.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.PerspectiveTransform3DInterpolationMode.Cubic
member.summary: Uses a 16 sample cubic kernel for interpolation. This mode uses the most processing time, but outputs a higher quality image.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.PerspectiveTransform3DInterpolationMode.MultisampleLinear
member.summary: Uses 4 linear samples within a single pixel for good edge anti-aliasing. This mode is good for scaling down by small amounts on images with few pixels.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.PerspectiveTransform3DInterpolationMode.Anisotropic
member.summary: Uses anisotropic filtering to sample a pattern according to the transformed shape of the bitmap.

member.name: T:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.RoundedRect
member.summary:
Contains the dimensions and corner radii of a rounded rectangle.
D2D1_ROUNDED_RECT
member.remarks:
Each corner of the rectangle specified by rect is replaced with a quarter ellipse, with a radius in each direction specified by radiusX and radiusY.
If radiusX is greater than or equal to half the width of the rectangle, and radiusY is greater than or equal to one-half the height, then the rounded rectangle is an ellipse with the same width and height of rect.
Even when both radiusX and radiusY are zero, the rounded rectangle is different from a rectangle. When stroked, the corners of the rounded rectangle are roundly joined, not mitered (square).

member.name: P:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.RoundedRect.Rect
member.summary: The coordinates of the rectangle.

member.name: P:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.RoundedRect.RadiusX
member.summary: The x-radius for the quarter ellipse that is drawn to replace every corner of the rectangle.

member.name: P:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.RoundedRect.RadiusY
member.summary: The y-radius for the quarter ellipse that is drawn to replace every corner of the rectangle.

member.name: T:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.ScaleInterpolationMode
member.summary:
The interpolation mode the Scale effect uses to scale the image. There are 6 scale modes that range in quality and speed.
D2D1_SCALE_INTERPOLATION_MODE

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.ScaleInterpolationMode.NearestNeighbor
member.summary: Samples the nearest single point and uses that. This mode uses less processing time, but outputs the lowest quality image.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.ScaleInterpolationMode.Linear
member.summary: Uses a four point sample and linear interpolation. This mode uses more processing time than the nearest neighbor mode, but outputs a higher quality image.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.ScaleInterpolationMode.Cubic
member.summary: Uses a 16 sample cubic kernel for interpolation. This mode uses the most processing time, but outputs a higher quality image.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.ScaleInterpolationMode.MultisampleLinear
member.summary: Uses 4 linear samples within a single pixel for good edge anti-aliasing. This mode is good for scaling down by small amounts on images with few pixels.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.ScaleInterpolationMode.Anisotropic
member.summary: Uses anisotropic filtering to sample a pattern according to the transformed shape of the bitmap.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.ScaleInterpolationMode.HighQualityCubic
member.summary: Uses a variable size high quality cubic kernel to perform a pre-downscale of the image if downscaling is involved in the transform matrix. Then uses the cubic interpolation mode for the final output.

member.name: T:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.ShadowOptimization
member.summary:
The level of performance optimization for the Shadow effect.
D2D1_SHADOW_OPTIMIZATION

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.ShadowOptimization.Speed
member.summary: Applies internal optimizations such as pre-scaling at relatively small radii. Uses linear filtering.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.ShadowOptimization.Balanced
member.summary: Uses the same optimization thresholds as Speed mode, but uses trilinear filtering.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.ShadowOptimization.Quality
member.summary: Only uses internal optimizations with large blur radii, where approximations are less likely to be visible. Uses trilinear filtering.

member.name: M:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.SpriteBatchExtensions.AddSprite(PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.ISpriteBatch,PaintDotNet.Rendering.RectFloat,System.Nullable{PaintDotNet.Rendering.RectInt32}@,System.Nullable{PaintDotNet.Imaging.ColorRgba128Float}@,System.Nullable{PaintDotNet.Rendering.Matrix3x2Float}@)
member.summary: Adds a single sprite to the end of this sprite batch.
member.param: The sprite batch object.
The destination rectangle specifying where to draw the sprite.
The source rectangle specifying the region of the source bitmap to draw as a sprite. The entire source bitmap will be used if this parameter is null or RectInt32.LogicallyInfinite.

The color to apply to the sprite. The output color is the result of component-wise multiplication of the source bitmap color and the provided color. The output color is not clamped. Direct2D will not change the color of the sprite if null is provided.
The transform to apply to the sprite's destination rectangle. Direct2D will not transform the destination rectangle of any sprite that is assigned a null value.
member.remarks: Always use a null value for properties you do not wish to use. This allows Direct2D to avoid storing values for those properties and to skip their handling entirely, which improves drawing speed. For example, suppose you have a batch of 500 sprites, and you do not wish to transform any of their destination rectangles. Rather than passing an array of identity matrices, simply omit the transforms parameter. This allows Direct2D to avoid storing any transforms and will yield the fastest drawing performance. On the other hand, if any sprite in the batch has any value set for a property, then internally Direct2D must allocate space for that property array and assign every sprite a value for that property (even if itâ€™s just the default value).

member.summary: Adds the given sprites to the end of this sprite batch. The number of sprites is governed by the length of the destinationRectangles parameter. You may use a 1-length span for the other spans to apply the same value for that property to each of the sprites. You may use a 0-length span for the other spans to use the default value associated with those properties, which can reduce memory usage and increase performance.
member.param: The sprite batch object.
The destination rectangles specifying where to draw the sprites.

The source rectangles specifying the regions of the source bitmap to draw as sprites. Direct2D will use the entire source bitmap for sprites that are assigned a null value or if RectInt32.LogicallyInfinite is used. If this span is empty, Direct2D will use the entire source bitmap for all of the added sprites.

The colors to apply to each sprite. The output color is the result of component-wise multiplication of the source bitmap color and the provided color. The output color is not clamped. Direct2D will not change the color of sprites that are assigned a null value. If this span is empty, then Direct2D will not change the color of any of the added sprites.

The transforms to apply to each sprite's destination recangle. Direct2D will not transform the destination rectangle of any sprites that are assigned a null value. If this span is empty then Direct2D will not transform the destination rectangle of any of the added sprites.
member.remarks: Always use an empty span for properties you do not wish to use. This allows Direct2D to avoid storing values for those properties and to skip their handling entirely, which improves drawing speed. For example, suppose you have a batch of 500 sprites, and you do not wish to transform any of their destination rectangles. Rather than passing an array of identity matrices, simply omit the transforms parameter. This allows Direct2D to avoid storing any transforms and will yield the fastest drawing performance. On the other hand, if any sprite in the batch has any value set for a property, then internally Direct2D must allocate space for that property array and assign every sprite a value for that property (even if itâ€™s just the default value).

member.name: T:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.SpriteOptions
member.summary:
Specifies additional aspects of how a sprite batch is to be drawn.
D2D1_SPRITE_OPTIONS

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.SpriteOptions.None
member.summary: Default value. No special drawing configuration. This option yields the best drawing performance.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.SpriteOptions.ClampToSourceRectangle
member.summary: Interpolation of bitmap pixels will be clamped to the spriteâ€™s source rectangle. If the sub-images in your source bitmap have no pixels separating them, then you may see color bleeding when drawing them with D2D1_SPRITE_OPTIONS_NONE. In that case, consider adding borders between them with your sprite-packing tool, or use this option. Note that drawing sprites with this option enabled is slower than using SpriteOptions.None.

member.name: T:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.SvgPathCommand
member.summary:
Represents a path commmand. Each command may reference floats from the segment data.
Commands ending in Absolute interpret data as absolute coordinate.
Commands ending in Relative interpret data as being relative to the previous point.
D2D1_SVG_PATH_COMMAND

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.SvgPathCommand.ClosePath
member.summary: Closes the current subpath. Uses no segment data.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.SvgPathCommand.MoveAbsolute
member.summary: Starts a new subpath at the coordinate (x y). Uses 2 floats of segment data.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.SvgPathCommand.MoveRelative
member.summary: Starts a new subpath at the coordinate (x y). Uses 2 floats of segment data.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.SvgPathCommand.LineAbsolute
member.summary: Draws a line to the coordinate (x y). Uses 2 floats of segment data.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.SvgPathCommand.LineRelative
member.summary: Draws a line to the coordinate (x y). Uses 2 floats of segment data.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.SvgPathCommand.CubicAbsolute
member.summary: Draws a cubic Bezier curve (x1 y1 x2 y2 x y). The curve ends at (x, y) and is defined by the two control points (x1, y1) and (x2, y2). Uses 6 floats of segment data.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.SvgPathCommand.CubicRelative
member.summary: Draws a cubic Bezier curve (x1 y1 x2 y2 x y). The curve ends at (x, y) and is defined by the two control points (x1, y1) and (x2, y2). Uses 6 floats of segment data.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.SvgPathCommand.QuadraticAbsolute
member.summary: Draws a quadratic Bezier curve (x1 y1 x y). The curve ends at (x, y) and is defined by the control point (x1 y1). Uses 4 floats of segment data.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.SvgPathCommand.QuadraticRelative
member.summary: Draws a quadratic Bezier curve (x1 y1 x y). The curve ends at (x, y) and is defined by the control point (x1 y1). Uses 4 floats of segment data.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.SvgPathCommand.ArcAbsolute
member.summary: Draws an elliptical arc (rx ry x-axis-rotation large-arc-flag sweep-flag x y). The curve ends at (x, y) and is defined by the arc parameters. The two flags are considered set if their values are non-zero. Uses 7 floats of segment data.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.SvgPathCommand.ArcRelative
member.summary: Draws an elliptical arc (rx ry x-axis-rotation large-arc-flag sweep-flag x y). The curve ends at (x, y) and is defined by the arc parameters. The two flags are considered set if their values are non-zero. Uses 7 floats of segment data.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.SvgPathCommand.HorizontalAbsolute
member.summary: Draws a horizontal line to the coordinate (x). Uses 1 float of segment data.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.SvgPathCommand.HorizontalRelative
member.summary: Draws a horizontal line to the coordinate (x). Uses 1 float of segment data.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.SvgPathCommand.VerticalAbsolute
member.summary: Draws a vertical line to the coordinate (y). Uses 1 float of segment data.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.SvgPathCommand.VerticalRelative
member.summary: Draws a vertical line to the coordinate (y). Uses 1 float of segment data.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.SvgPathCommand.CubicSmoothAbsolute
member.summary: Draws a smooth cubic Bezier curve (x2 y2 x y). The curve ends at (x, y) and is defined by the control point (x2, y2). Uses 4 floats of segment data.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.SvgPathCommand.CubicSmoothRelative
member.summary: Draws a smooth cubic Bezier curve (x2 y2 x y). The curve ends at (x, y) and is defined by the control point (x2, y2). Uses 4 floats of segment data.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.SvgPathCommand.QuadraticSmoothRelative
member.summary: Draws a smooth quadratic Bezier curve ending at (x, y). Uses 2 floats of segment data.

member.name: T:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.TextureFilter
member.summary:
Represents filtering modes that a transform may select to use on input textures.
D2D1_FILTER
member.remarks: The most common choices are (point / nearest neighbor) and (linear / bilinear).

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.TextureFilter.MinMagMipPoint
member.summary: Use point sampling for minification, magnification, and mip-level sampling. This is equivalent to InterpolationMode.NearestNeighbor.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.TextureFilter.MinMagPointMipLinear
member.summary: Use point sampling for minification and magnification; use linear interpolation for mip-level sampling.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.TextureFilter.MinPointMagLinearMipPoint
member.summary: Use point sampling for minification; use linear interpolation for magnification; use point sampling for mip-level sampling.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.TextureFilter.MinPointMagMipLinear
member.summary: Use point sampling for minification; use linear interpolation for magnification and mip-level sampling.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.TextureFilter.MinLinearMagMipPoint
member.summary: Use linear interpolation for minification; use point sampling for magnification and mip-level sampling.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.TextureFilter.MinLinearMagPointMipLinear
member.summary: Use linear interpolation for minification; use point sampling for magnification; use linear interpolation for mip-level sampling.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.TextureFilter.MinMagLinearMipPoint
member.summary: Use linear interpolation for minification and magnification; use point sampling for mip-level sampling.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.TextureFilter.MinMagMipLinear
member.summary: Use linear interpolation for minification, magnification, and mip-level sampling. This is equivalent to InterpolationMode.Linear.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.TextureFilter.Anisotropic
member.summary: Use anisotropic interpolation for minification, magnification, and mip-level sampling.

member.name: T:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.Transform3DInterpolationMode
member.summary:
The interpolation mode the Transform3D effect uses on the image. There are 5 scale modes that range in quality and speed.
D2D1_3DTRANSFORM_INTERPOLATION_MODE

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.Transform3DInterpolationMode.NearestNeighbor
member.summary: Samples the nearest single point and uses that. This mode uses less processing time, but outputs the lowest quality image.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.Transform3DInterpolationMode.Linear
member.summary: Uses a four point sample and linear interpolation. This mode uses more processing time than the nearest neighbor mode, but outputs a higher quality image.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.Transform3DInterpolationMode.Cubic
member.summary: Uses a 16 sample cubic kernel for interpolation. This mode uses the most processing time, but outputs a higher quality image.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.Transform3DInterpolationMode.MultisampleLinear
member.summary: Uses 4 linear samples within a single pixel for good edge anti-aliasing. This mode is good for scaling down by small amounts on images with few pixels.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.Transform3DInterpolationMode.Anisotropic
member.summary: Uses anisotropic filtering to sample a pattern according to the transformed shape of the bitmap.

member.name: T:PaintDotNet.Direct2D1.WindowState
member.summary:
Describes whether a window is occluded.
D2D1_WINDOW_STATE
member.remarks: If the window was occluded the last time was called, the next time the device context calls , it returns regardless of the current window state. If you want to use CheckWindowState to check the current window state, call CheckWindowState after every EndDraw call and ignore its return value. This will ensure that your next call to CheckWindowState state returns the actual window state.

member.summary: The window is not occluded.

member.name: T:PaintDotNet.DirectWrite.BreakCondition
member.summary: Indicates the condition at the edges of inline object or text used to determine line-breaking behavior.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.DirectWrite.BreakCondition.Neutral
member.summary: Indicates whether a break is allowed by determining the condition of the neighboring text span or inline object.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.DirectWrite.BreakCondition.CanBreak
member.summary: Indicates that a line break is allowed, unless overruled by the condition of the neighboring text span or inline object, either prohibited by a "may not break" condition or forced by a "must break" condition.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.DirectWrite.BreakCondition.MayNotBreak
member.summary: Indicates that there should be no line break, unless overruled by a "must break" condition from the neighboring text span or inline object.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.DirectWrite.BreakCondition.MustBreak
member.summary: Indicates that the line break must happen, regardless of the condition of the adjacent text span or inline object.

member.name: T:PaintDotNet.DirectWrite.FontMetrics
member.summary:
The FontMetrics structure specifies the metrics that are applicable to all glyphs within the font face.
See DWRITE_FONT_METRICS1 for more information.

member.name: P:PaintDotNet.DirectWrite.FontMetrics.DesignUnitsPerEm
member.summary: The number of font design units per em unit. Font files use their own coordinate system of font design units. A font design unit is the smallest measurable unit in the em square, an imaginary square that is used to size and align glyphs. The concept of em square is used as a reference scale factor when defining font size and device transformation semantics. The size of one em square is also commonly used to compute the paragraph indentation value.

member.name: P:PaintDotNet.DirectWrite.FontMetrics.Ascent
member.summary: The ascent value of the font face in font design units. Ascent is the distance from the top of font character alignment box to the English baseline.

member.name: P:PaintDotNet.DirectWrite.FontMetrics.Descent
member.summary: The descent value of the font face in font design units. Descent is the distance from the bottom of font character alignment box to the English baseline.

member.name: P:PaintDotNet.DirectWrite.FontMetrics.LineGap
member.summary: The line gap in font design units. Recommended additional white space to add between lines to improve legibility. The recommended line spacing (baseline-to-baseline distance) is the sum of ascent, descent, and lineGap. The line gap is usually positive or zero but can be negative, in which case the recommended line spacing is less than the height of the character alignment box.

member.name: P:PaintDotNet.DirectWrite.FontMetrics.CapHeight
member.summary: The cap height value of the font face in font design units. Cap height is the distance from the English baseline to the top of a typical English capital. Capital "H" is often used as a reference character for the purpose of calculating the cap height value.

member.name: P:PaintDotNet.DirectWrite.FontMetrics.XHeight
member.summary: The x-height value of the font face in font design units. x-height is the distance from the English baseline to the top of lowercase letter "x", or a similar lowercase character.

member.name: P:PaintDotNet.DirectWrite.FontMetrics.UnderlinePosition
member.summary: The underline position value of the font face in font design units. Underline position is the position of underline relative to the English baseline. The value is usually made negative in order to place the underline below the baseline.

member.name: P:PaintDotNet.DirectWrite.FontMetrics.UnderlineThickness
member.summary: The suggested underline thickness value of the font face in font design units.

member.name: P:PaintDotNet.DirectWrite.FontMetrics.StrikethroughPosition
member.summary: The strikethrough position value of the font face in font design units. Strikethrough position is the position of strikethrough relative to the English baseline. The value is usually made positive in order to place the strikethrough above the baseline.

member.name: P:PaintDotNet.DirectWrite.FontMetrics.StrikethroughThickness
member.summary: The suggested strikethrough thickness value of the font face in font design units.

member.name: P:PaintDotNet.DirectWrite.FontMetrics.GlyphBoxLeft
member.summary: Left edge of accumulated bounding blackbox of all glyphs in the font.

member.name: P:PaintDotNet.DirectWrite.FontMetrics.GlyphBoxTop
member.summary: Top edge of accumulated bounding blackbox of all glyphs in the font.

member.name: P:PaintDotNet.DirectWrite.FontMetrics.GlyphBoxRight
member.summary: Right edge of accumulated bounding blackbox of all glyphs in the font.

member.name: P:PaintDotNet.DirectWrite.FontMetrics.GlyphBoxBottom
member.summary: Bottom edge of accumulated bounding blackbox of all glyphs in the font.

member.name: P:PaintDotNet.DirectWrite.FontMetrics.SubscriptPositionX
member.summary: Horizontal position of the subscript relative to the baseline origin. This is typically negative (to the left) in italic and oblique fonts, and zero in regular fonts.

member.name: P:PaintDotNet.DirectWrite.FontMetrics.SubscriptPositionY
member.summary: Vertical position of the subscript relative to the baseline. This is typically negative.

member.name: P:PaintDotNet.DirectWrite.FontMetrics.SubscriptSizeX
member.summary: Horizontal size of the subscript em box in design units, used to scale the simulated subscript relative to the full em box size. This is the numerator of the scaling ratio where denominator is the design units per em. If this member is zero, the font does not specify a scale factor, and the client uses its own policy.

member.name: P:PaintDotNet.DirectWrite.FontMetrics.SubscriptSizeY
member.summary: Vertical size of the subscript em box in design units, used to scale the simulated subscript relative to the full em box size. This is the numerator of the scaling ratio where denominator is the design units per em. If this member is zero, the font does not specify a scale factor, and the client uses its own policy.

member.name: P:PaintDotNet.DirectWrite.FontMetrics.SuperscriptPositionX
member.summary: Horizontal position of the superscript relative to the baseline origin. This is typically positive (to the right) in italic and oblique fonts, and zero in regular fonts.

member.name: P:PaintDotNet.DirectWrite.FontMetrics.SuperscriptPositionY
member.summary: Vertical position of the superscript relative to the baseline. This is typically positive.

member.name: P:PaintDotNet.DirectWrite.FontMetrics.SuperscriptSizeX
member.summary: Horizontal size of the superscript em box in design units, used to scale the simulated superscript relative to the full em box size. This is the numerator of the scaling ratio where denominator is the design units per em. If this member is zero, the font does not specify a scale factor, and the client should use its own policy.

member.name: P:PaintDotNet.DirectWrite.FontMetrics.SuperscriptSizeY
member.summary: Vertical size of the superscript em box in design units, used to scale the simulated superscript relative to the full em box size. This is the numerator of the scaling ratio where denominator is the design units per em. If this member is zero, the font does not specify a scale factor, and the client should use its own policy.

member.name: P:PaintDotNet.DirectWrite.FontMetrics.HasTypographicMetrics
member.summary: A boolean value that indicates that the ascent, descent, and lineGap are based on newer 'typographic' values in the font, rather than legacy values.

member.name: T:PaintDotNet.DirectWrite.FontSimulations
member.summary: Specifies algorithmic style simulations to be applied to the font face. Bold and oblique simulations can be combined via bitwise OR operation.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.DirectWrite.FontSimulations.None
member.summary: Indicates that no simulations are applied to the font face.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.DirectWrite.FontSimulations.Bold
member.summary: Indicates that algorithmic emboldening is applied to the font face. Increases weight by applying a widening algorithm to the glyph outline. This may be used to simulate a bold weight where no designed bold weight is available.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.DirectWrite.FontSimulations.Oblique
member.summary: Indicates that algorithmic italicization is applied to the font face. Applies obliquing (shear) to the glyph outline. This may be used to simulate an oblique/italic style where no designed oblique/italic style is available.

member.name: T:PaintDotNet.DirectWrite.FontStretch
member.summary: Represents the degree to which a font has been stretched compared to a font's normal aspect ratio.The enumerated values correspond to the usWidthClass definition in the OpenType specification. The usWidthClass represents an integer value between 1 and 9â€”lower values indicate narrower widths; higher values indicate wider widths.

member.name: T:PaintDotNet.DirectWrite.FontStyle
member.summary: Represents the style of a font face as normal, italic, or oblique.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.DirectWrite.FontStyle.Normal
member.summary: The characters in a normal, or roman, font are upright.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.DirectWrite.FontStyle.Oblique
member.summary: The characters in an oblique font are artificially slanted.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.DirectWrite.FontStyle.Italic
member.summary: The characters in an italic font are truly slanted and appear as they were designed.

member.name: T:PaintDotNet.DirectWrite.FontWeight
member.summary:
Represents the density of a typeface, in terms of the lightness or heaviness of the strokes. The enumerated values correspond to the usWeightClass definition in the OpenType specification. The usWeightClass represents an integer value between 1 and 999. Lower values indicate lighter weights; higher values indicate heavier weights.
See DWRITE_FONT_WEIGHT for more information.

member.name: T:PaintDotNet.DirectWrite.GlyphImageFormats
member.summary:
Specifies which formats are supported in the font, either at a font-wide level or per glyph.
DWRITE_GLYPH_IMAGE_FORMATS

member.name: T:PaintDotNet.DirectWrite.GridFitMode
member.summary: Specifies whether to enable grid-fitting of glyph outlines (also known as hinting).

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.DirectWrite.GridFitMode.Default
member.summary: Choose grid fitting based on the font's table information.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.DirectWrite.GridFitMode.Disabled
member.summary: Always disable grid fitting, using the ideal glyph outlines.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.DirectWrite.GridFitMode.Enabled
member.summary: Enable grid fitting, adjusting glyph outlines for device pixel display.

member.summary: true if the text range is trimmed; otherwise, false.

member.name: P:PaintDotNet.DirectWrite.HitTestPointResult.IsTrailingHit
member.summary: A flag that indicates whether the hit-test location is at the leading or the trailing side of the character. When the IsInside value is set to FALSE, this value is set according to the output Metrics.TextPosition value to represent the edge closest to the hit-test location.

member.name: P:PaintDotNet.DirectWrite.HitTestPointResult.IsInside
member.summary: An output flag that indicates whether the hit-test location is inside the text string. When FALSE, the position nearest the text's edge is returned.

member.name: P:PaintDotNet.DirectWrite.HitTestPointResult.Metrics
member.summary: The output geometry fully enclosing the hit-test location. When the output IsInside value is set to FALSE, this structure represents the geometry enclosing the edge closest to the hit-test location.

member.name: P:PaintDotNet.DirectWrite.HitTestTextPositionResult.Point
member.summary: Contains the output pixel location, relative to the top-left location of the layout box.

member.name: P:PaintDotNet.DirectWrite.HitTestTextPositionResult.Metrics
member.summary: Contains the output geometry fully enclosing the specified text position.

member.name: T:PaintDotNet.DirectWrite.IDirectWriteFactory
member.summary:
Used to create all subsequent DirectWrite objects. This interface is the root factory interface for all DirectWrite objects.
This interface corresponds to the following DirectWrite interfaces:
IDWriteFactory IDWriteFactory1 IDWriteFactory2 IDWriteFactory3 IDWriteFactory4 IDWriteFactory5 IDWriteFactory6 IDWriteFactory7
NOTE: Not all DirectWrite functionality is supported.

member.name: P:PaintDotNet.DirectWrite.InlineObjectMetrics.Width
member.summary: The width of the inline object.

member.name: P:PaintDotNet.DirectWrite.InlineObjectMetrics.Height
member.summary: The height of the inline object.

member.name: P:PaintDotNet.DirectWrite.InlineObjectMetrics.Baseline
member.summary: The distance from the top of the object to the point where it is lined up with the adjacent text. If the baseline is at the bottom, then Baseline simply equals Height.

member.name: P:PaintDotNet.DirectWrite.InlineObjectMetrics.SupportsSideways
member.summary: A flag that indicates whether the object is to be placed upright or alongside the text baseline for vertical text.

member.name: T:PaintDotNet.DirectWrite.LineMetrics
member.summary: Contains information about a formatted line of text.

member.name: P:PaintDotNet.DirectWrite.LineMetrics.Length
member.summary: The number of text positions in the text line. This includes any trailing whitespace and newline characters.

member.name: P:PaintDotNet.DirectWrite.LineMetrics.TrailingWhitespaceLength
member.summary: The number of whitespace positions at the end of the text line. Newline sequences are considered whitespace.

member.name: P:PaintDotNet.DirectWrite.LineMetrics.NewlineLength
member.summary: The number of characters in the newline sequence at the end of the text line. If the count is zero, then the text line was either wrapped or it is the end of the text.

member.name: P:PaintDotNet.DirectWrite.LineMetrics.Height
member.summary: The height of the text line.

member.name: P:PaintDotNet.DirectWrite.LineMetrics.Baseline
member.summary: The distance from the top of the text line to its baseline.

member.name: P:PaintDotNet.DirectWrite.LineMetrics.IsTrimmed
member.summary: The line is trimmed.

member.name: P:PaintDotNet.DirectWrite.LineMetrics.LeadingBefore
member.summary: White space before the content of the line. This is included in the line height and baseline distances. If the line is formatted horizontally either with a uniform line spacing or with proportional line spacing, this value represents the extra space above the content.

member.name: P:PaintDotNet.DirectWrite.LineMetrics.LeadingAfter
member.summary: White space after the content of the line. This is included in the height of the line. If the line is formatted horizontally either with a uniform line spacing or with proportional line spacing, this value represents the extra space below the content.

member.name: T:PaintDotNet.DirectWrite.LineSpacing
member.summary: Sets the vertical spacing between lines of text.

member.name: P:PaintDotNet.DirectWrite.LineSpacing.Method
member.summary: Method used to determine line spacing.

member.name: P:PaintDotNet.DirectWrite.LineSpacing.Height
member.summary: Spacing between lines. The interpretation of this parameter depends upon the line spacing method, as follows: * Default line spacing: ignored * Uniform line spacing: explicit distance in DIPs between lines * Proportional line spacing: a scaling factor to be applied to the computed line height; for each line, the height of the line is computed as for default line spacing, and the scaling factor is applied to that value.

member.name: P:PaintDotNet.DirectWrite.LineSpacing.Baseline
member.summary: Distance from top of line to baseline. The interpretation of this parameter depends upon the line spacing method, as follows: * Default line spacing: ignored * Uniform line spacing: explicit distance in DIPs from the top of the line to the baseline * Proportional line spacing: a scaling factor applied to the computed baseline; for each line, the baseline distance is computed as for default line spacing, and the scaling factor is applied to that value.

member.name: P:PaintDotNet.DirectWrite.LineSpacing.LeadingBefore
member.summary: Proportion of the entire leading distributed before the line. The allowed value is between 0 and 1.0. The remaining leading is distributed after the line. It is ignored for the default and uniform line spacing methods. The leading that is available to distribute before or after the line depends on the values of the height and baseline parameters.

member.name: P:PaintDotNet.DirectWrite.LineSpacing.FontLineGapUsage
member.summary: Specifies whether the font metrics' line gap value should be part of the line metrics.

member.name: T:PaintDotNet.DirectWrite.LineSpacingMethod
member.summary: The method used for line spacing in a text layout.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.DirectWrite.LineSpacingMethod.Default
member.summary: Line spacing depends solely on the content, adjusting to accommodate the size of fonts and inline objects.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.DirectWrite.LineSpacingMethod.Uniform
member.summary: Lines are explicitly set to uniform spacing, regardless of the size of fonts and inline objects. This can be useful to avoid the uneven appearance that can occur from font fallback.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.DirectWrite.LineSpacingMethod.Proportional
member.summary: Line spacing and baseline distances are proportional to the computed values based on the content, the size of the fonts and inline objects.

member.name: T:PaintDotNet.DirectWrite.OverhangMetrics
member.summary: Indicates how much any visible DIPs (device independent pixels) overshoot each side of the layout or inline objects.
member.remarks: Positive overhangs indicate that the visible area extends outside the layout box or inline object, while negative values mean there is whitespace inside. The returned values are unaffected by rendering transforms or pixel snapping. Additionally, they may not exactly match the final target's pixel bounds after applying grid fitting and hinting.

member.name: P:PaintDotNet.DirectWrite.OverhangMetrics.Left
member.summary: Gets the distance from the left-most visible DIP to its alignment edge.

member.name: P:PaintDotNet.DirectWrite.OverhangMetrics.Top
member.summary: Gets the distance from the top-most visible DIP to its alignment edge.

member.name: P:PaintDotNet.DirectWrite.OverhangMetrics.Right
member.summary: Gets the distance from the right-most visible DIP to its alignment edge.

member.name: P:PaintDotNet.DirectWrite.OverhangMetrics.Bottom
member.summary: Gets the distance from the bottom-most visible DIP to its alignment edge.

member.name: T:PaintDotNet.DirectWrite.ParagraphAlignment
member.summary: Specifies the alignment of paragraph text along the flow direction axis, relative to the top and bottom of the flow's layout box.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.DirectWrite.ParagraphAlignment.Near
member.summary: The top of the text flow is aligned to the top edge of the layout box.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.DirectWrite.ParagraphAlignment.Far
member.summary: The bottom of the text flow is aligned to the bottom edge of the layout box.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.DirectWrite.ParagraphAlignment.Center
member.summary: The center of the flow is aligned to the center of the layout box.

member.name: T:PaintDotNet.DirectWrite.PixelGeometry
member.summary: Represents the internal structure of a device pixel (that is, the physical arrangement of red, green, and blue color components) that is assumed for purposes of rendering text.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.DirectWrite.PixelGeometry.Flat
member.summary: The red, green, and blue color components of each pixel are assumed to occupy the same point.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.DirectWrite.PixelGeometry.Rgb
member.summary: Each pixel is composed of three vertical stripes, with red on the left, green in the center, and blue on the right. This is the most common pixel geometry for LCD monitors.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.DirectWrite.PixelGeometry.Bgr
member.summary: Each pixel is composed of three vertical stripes, with blue on the left, green in the center, and red on the right.

member.name: T:PaintDotNet.DirectWrite.ReadingDirection
member.summary: Specifies the direction in which reading progresses.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.DirectWrite.TextMeasuringMode.Natural
member.summary: Specifies that text is measured using glyph ideal metrics whose values are independent to the current display resolution.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.DirectWrite.TextMeasuringMode.GdiClassic
member.summary: Specifies that text is measured using glyph display-compatible metrics whose values tuned for the current display resolution.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.DirectWrite.TextMeasuringMode.GdiNatural
member.summary: Specifies that text is measured using the same glyph display metrics as text measured by GDI using a font created with CLEARTYPE_NATURAL_QUALITY.

member.name: T:PaintDotNet.DirectWrite.TextMetrics
member.summary: Contains the metrics associated with text after layout. All coordinates are in device independent pixels (DIPs).

member.name: P:PaintDotNet.DirectWrite.TextMetrics.Left
member.summary: A value that indicates the left-most point of formatted text relative to the layout box, while excluding any glyph overhang.

member.name: P:PaintDotNet.DirectWrite.TextMetrics.Top
member.summary: A value that indicates the top-most point of formatted text relative to the layout box, while excluding any glyph overhang.

member.name: P:PaintDotNet.DirectWrite.TextMetrics.Width
member.summary: A value that indicates the width of the formatted text, while ignoring trailing whitespace at the end of each line.

member.name: P:PaintDotNet.DirectWrite.TextMetrics.WidthIncludingTrailingWhitespace
member.summary: The width of the formatted text, taking into account the trailing whitespace at the end of each line.

member.name: P:PaintDotNet.DirectWrite.TextMetrics.WidthMax
member.summary: Gets the maximum value of Width and WidthIncludingTrailingWhitespace.

member.name: P:PaintDotNet.DirectWrite.TextMetrics.Height
member.summary: The height of the formatted text. The height of an empty string is set to the same value as that of the default font.

member.name: P:PaintDotNet.DirectWrite.TextMetrics.HeightIncludingTrailingWhitespace
member.summary: The height of the formatted text taking into account the trailing whitespace at the end of each line. This is pertinent for vertical text.

member.name: P:PaintDotNet.DirectWrite.TextMetrics.HeightMax
member.summary: Gets the maximum value of Height and HeightIncludingTrailingWhitespace.

member.name: P:PaintDotNet.DirectWrite.TextMetrics.LayoutWidth
member.summary: The initial width given to the layout. It can be either larger or smaller than the text content width, depending on whether the text was wrapped.

member.name: P:PaintDotNet.DirectWrite.TextMetrics.LayoutHeight
member.summary: Initial height given to the layout. Depending on the length of the text, it may be larger or smaller than the text content height.

member.name: P:PaintDotNet.DirectWrite.TextMetrics.MaxBidiReorderingDepth
member.summary: The maximum reordering count of any line of text, used to calculate the most number of hit-testing boxes needed. If the layout has no bidirectional text, or no text at all, the minimum level is 1.

member.name: T:PaintDotNet.DirectWrite.TextRenderingMode
member.summary: Represents a method of rendering glyphs.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.DirectWrite.TextRenderingMode.Default
member.summary: Specifies that the rendering mode is determined automatically, based on the font and size.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.DirectWrite.TextRenderingMode.Aliased
member.summary: Specifies that no anti-aliasing is performed. Each pixel is either set to the foreground color of the text or retains the color of the background.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.DirectWrite.TextRenderingMode.GdiClassic
member.summary: Specifies that antialiasing is performed in the horizontal direction and the appearance of glyphs is layout-compatible with GDI using CLEARTYPE_QUALITY. Use TextMeasuringMode.GdiClassic to get glyph advances. The antialiasing may be either ClearType or grayscale depending on the text antialiasing mode.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.DirectWrite.TextRenderingMode.GdiNatural
member.summary: Specifies that antialiasing is performed in the horizontal direction and the appearance of glyphs is layout-compatible with GDI using CLEARTYPE_NATURAL_QUALITY. Glyph advances are close to the font design advances, but are still rounded to whole pixels. Use TextMeasuringMode.GdiNatural to get glyph advances. The antialiasing may be either ClearType or grayscale depending on the text antialiasing mode.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.DirectWrite.TextRenderingMode.Natural
member.summary: Specifies that antialiasing is performed in the horizontal direction. This rendering mode allows glyphs to be positioned with subpixel precision and is therefore suitable for natural (i.e., resolution-independent) layout. The antialiasing may be either ClearType or grayscale depending on the text antialiasing mode.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.DirectWrite.TextRenderingMode.NaturalSymmetric
member.summary: Similar to natural mode except that antialiasing is performed in both the horizontal and vertical directions. This is typically used at larger sizes to make curves and diagonal lines look smoother. The antialiasing may be either ClearType or grayscale depending on the text antialiasing mode.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.DirectWrite.TextRenderingMode.Outline
member.summary: Specifies that rendering should bypass the rasterizer and use the outlines directly. This is typically used at very large sizes.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.DirectWrite.TextRenderingMode.NaturalSymmetricDownsampled
member.summary: Similar to natural symmetric mode except that when possible, text should be rasterized in a downsampled form.

member.name: T:PaintDotNet.DirectWrite.TrimmingGranularity
member.summary: Specifies the text granularity used to trim text overflowing the layout box.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.DirectWrite.TrimmingGranularity.None
member.summary: No trimming occurs. Text flows beyond the layout width.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.DirectWrite.TrimmingGranularity.Character
member.summary: Trimming occurs at a character cluster boundary.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.DirectWrite.TrimmingGranularity.Word
member.summary: Trimming occurs at a word boundary.

member.name: P:PaintDotNet.DirectWrite.TrimmingParameters.Granularity
member.summary: A value that specifies the text granularity used to trim text overflowing the layout box.

member.name: P:PaintDotNet.DirectWrite.TrimmingParameters.Delimiter
member.summary: A character code used as the delimiter that signals the beginning of the portion of text to be preserved. Text starting from the Nth occurrence of the delimiter (where N equals delimiterCount) counting backwards from the end of the text block will be preserved. For example, given the text is a path like c:\A\B\C\D\file.txt and delimiter equal to '' and delimiterCount equal to 1, the file.txt portion of the text would be preserved. Specifying a delimiterCount of 2 would preserve D\file.txt.

member.name: P:PaintDotNet.DirectWrite.TrimmingParameters.DelimiterCount
member.summary: The delimiter count, counting from the end of the text, to preserve text from.

member.name: T:PaintDotNet.DirectWrite.UnexpectedDirectWriteException
member.summary: Indicates an error originating in DirectWrite code, which is not expected to occur but is safe to recover from.

member.name: T:PaintDotNet.DirectWrite.WordWrapping
member.summary: Specifies the word wrapping to be used in a particular multiline paragraph.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.DirectWrite.WordWrapping.Wrap
member.summary: Indicates that words are broken across lines to avoid text overflowing the layout box.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.DirectWrite.WordWrapping.NoWrap
member.summary: Indicates that words are kept within the same line even when it overflows the layout box. This option is often used with scrolling to reveal overflow text.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.DirectWrite.WordWrapping.EmergencyBreak
member.summary: Words are broken across lines to avoid text overflowing the layout box. Emergency wrapping occurs if the word is larger than the maximum width.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.DirectWrite.WordWrapping.WholeWord
member.summary: When emergency wrapping, only wrap whole words, never breaking words when the layout width is too small for even a single word.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.DirectWrite.WordWrapping.Character
member.summary: Wrap between any valid character clusters.

member.name: T:PaintDotNet.Dxgi.DxgiAlphaMode
member.summary:
Identifies the alpha value, transparency behavior, of a surface.
DXGI_ALPHA_MODE

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.Dxgi.DxgiAlphaMode.Unspecified
member.summary: Indicates that the transparency behavior is not specified.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.Dxgi.DxgiAlphaMode.Premultiplied
member.summary: Indicates that the transparency behavior is premultiplied. Each color is first scaled by the alpha value. The alpha value itself is the same in both straight and premultiplied alpha. Typically, no color channel value is greater than the alpha channel value. If a color channel value in a premultiplied format is greater than the alpha channel, the standard source-over blending math results in an additive blend.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.Dxgi.DxgiAlphaMode.Straight
member.summary: Indicates that the transparency behavior is not premultiplied. The alpha channel indicates the transparency of the color.

member.name: F:PaintDotNet.Dxgi.DxgiAlphaMode.Ignore
member.summary: Indicates to ignore the transparency behavior.

summary.para: This is the standard definition for sRGB.
Note that this is often implemented with a linear segment, but in that case the exponent is corrected to stay aligned with a gamma 2.2 curve.
This is usually used with 8 or 10 bit color channels.
This is the standard definition for scRGB, and is usually used with 16 bit integer, 16 bit floating point, or 32 bit floating point color channels.
This is the standard definition for ITU-R Recommendation BT.709. Note that due to the inclusion of a linear segment, the transfer curve looks similar to a pure exponential gamma of 1.9.
This is usually used with 8 or 10 bit color channels.
This is usually used with 10 or 12 bit color channels.
Reserved.
This definition is commonly used for JPG, and is usually used with 8, 10, or 12 bit color channels.
This definition is commonly used for MPEG2, and is usually used with 8, 10, or 12 bit color channels.
This is sometimes used for H.264 camera capture, and is usually used with 8, 10, or 12 bit color channels.
This definition is commonly used for H.264 and HEVC, and is usually used with 8, 10, or 12 bit color channels.
This is sometimes used for H.264 camera capture, and is usually used with 8, 10, or 12 bit color channels.
This definition may be used by HEVC, and is usually used with 10 or 12 bit color channels.
This is usually used with 10 or 12 bit color channels.

member.name: T:PaintDotNet.Interop.CustomImplementationAllowedAttribute
member.summary: This attribute is placed on native-mapped interfaces that derive from IObjectRef. It allows documenting which interfaces allow custom implementations. What this means is that you can implement this interface in managed code, and over on the native side there is a CCW (COM Callable Wrapper) that adapts this interface.
member.remarks: If this attribute is not on an interface, then custom implementations are not allowed, and native/COM code will only see it as an opaque IUnknown* reference.

member.name: T:PaintDotNet.Interop.IComObject
member.summary: Implemented by an object that wraps a COM object.

member.name: T:PaintDotNet.Interop.PreferDerivedInterfaceAttribute
member.summary:
When creating a proxy or RCW for a natively mapped interface, this attribute on the managed interface will instruct the runtime to first query for the derived interface when the base interface is requested. If that query succeeds, then the wrapper or proxy for the derived interface will be created instead.
This is intended to be used on interfaces that have been succeeded by newer versions. Applying this attribute is an optimization that can help reduce the number of proxies that must be instantiated by way of allowing casting to be employed instead.
For example:
[PreferDerivedInterface(typeof(IStrokeStyle1))] public interface IStrokeStyle : IObjectRef { ... }

member.name: T:PaintDotNet.Interop.SpeciatedInterfaceAttribute
member.summary:
Indicates that an interface is "speciated". This expands a native interface into multiple managed interfaces ("species"), including the base managed interface which maps directly to the native interface.
When this attribute is present, the managed wrapper must have static methods called TryCreateSpeciesWrapper and TryCreateSpeciesProxy.
Examples:
IBitmapSource is speciated via IBitmapSource<TPixel>. A specific managed interface is chosen based on the bitmap's pixel format. The base interface, IBitmapSource, is still used when a pixel format does not have a more refined interface available.
IColorContext is speciated based on its Type property into IExifColorSpaceColorContext or IProfileColorContext.

member.name: T:PaintDotNet.Interop.WeakComObjectMap
member.summary: Maintains a mapping from COM objects, via canonical IUnknown pointers, to associated managed objects that are associated with them. This can be used to implement an RCW cache, or something similar.
member.remarks: This class does not maintain references to the COM objects. Therefore, it is required that the managed objects maintain a native reference to the COM object. This guarantees that a lookup from the COM object pointer to the managed object will be correct, and that the COM object pointer will not be a recycled allocation.
